'''Anomalous experiences''', such as so-called benign [[hallucination]]s, may occur in a person in a state of good mental and physical health, even in the apparent absence of a transient trigger factor such as [[fatigue (medical)|fatigue]], [[Substance intoxication|intoxication]] or [[sensory deprivation]]. The evidence for this statement has been accumulating for more than a century. Studies of benign hallucinatory experiences go back to 1886 and the early work of the [[Society for Psychical Research]],Gurney, E., Myers, F.W.H. and Podmore, F. (1886). ''Phantasms of the Living'', Vols. I and II. London: Trubner and Co..Sidgwick, Eleanor; Johnson, Alice; and others (1894). Report on the Census of Hallucinations, London: ''Proceedings of the Society for Psychical Research'', Vol. X. which suggested approximately 10% of the population had experienced at least one hallucinatory episode in the course of their life. More recent studies have validated these findings; the precise incidence found varies with the nature of the episode and the criteria of "hallucination" adopted, but the basic finding is now well-supported.See Slade, P.D. and Bentall, R.P. (1988). ''Sensory Deception: a scientific analysis of hallucination''. London: Croom Helm, for a review. == Types == Of particular interest, for reasons to be discussed below, are those anomalous experiences which are characterised by extreme perceptual realism. ===Apparitional experiences=== A common type of anomalous experience is the [[apparitional experience]], which may be defined as one in which a subject seems to perceive some person or thing that is not physically present. Self-selected samples tend to report a predominance of human figures, but apparitions of animals,See, for example, Green, C., and McCreery, C. (1975). ''Apparitions''. London: Hamish Hamilton, pp. 192-196. and even objects''Apparitions'', pp. 197-199. are also reported. Notably, the majority of the human figures reported in such samples are not recognised by the subject, and of those who are, not all are of deceased persons; apparitions of living persons have also been reported.''Apparitions'', pp. 178-183. ===Out-of-body experiences=== [[Out-of-body experiences]] (OBEs) have become to some extent conflated in the public mind with the concept of the [[near-death experience]]. However, the evidence suggests that the majority of out-of-body experiences do not occur near death, but in conditions of either very high or very low arousal.Irwin, H.J. (1985). ''Flight of Mind: a psychological study of the out-of-body experience.'' Metuchen, New Jersey: The Scarecrow Press. McCreery McCreery, C. (2008). Dreams and psychosis: a new look at an old hypothesis. ''Psychological Paper No. 2008-1''. Oxford: Oxford Forum. [http://www.celiagreen.com/charlesmccreery/dreams-and-psychosis.pdf Online PDF] has suggested that this latter paradox may be explained by reference to the fact that sleep may be approached, not only by the conventional route of low arousal and deafferentation, but also by the less familiar route of extreme stress and hyper-arousal.Oswald, I. (1962). ''Sleeping and Waking: Physiology and Psychology.'' Amsterdam: Elsevier. On this model OBEs represent the intrusion of Stage 1 sleep processes into waking consciousness. OBEs can be regarded as hallucinatory in the sense that they are perceptual or quasi-perceptual experiences in which by definition the ostensible viewpoint is not coincident with the physical body of the subject. Therefore, the normal sensory input, if any, that the subject is receiving during the experience cannot correspond exactly to the perceptual representation of the world in the subject's consciousness. As with hallucinatory experiences in general, attempts to survey samples of the general population have suggested that such experiences are relatively common, incidence figures of between 15 and 25 percent being commonly reported.See Irwin, ''op.cit.,'' for a review. The variation is presumably to be accounted for by the different types of populations sampled and the different criteria of ‘out-of-body experience’ used. ===Dreams and lucid dreams=== {{Main|Dream|Lucid dream}} A dream has been defined by some (e.g. ''Encyclopædia Britannica'') as a hallucinatory experience during sleep. A lucid dream may be defined as one in which the dreamer is aware that he or she is asleep and dreaming. The term ‘lucid dream’ was first used by the Dutch physician Frederik van Eeden,van Eeden, F. (1913). A study of dreams. ''Proceedings of the Society for Psychical Research'', '''26''', Part 47, pp. 431-461. who studied his own dreams of this type. The word ‘lucid’ refers to the fact that the subject has achieved insight into his or her condition, rather than the perceptual quality of the experience. Nevertheless, it is one of the features of lucid dreams that they can have an extremely high quality of perceptual realism, to the extent that the dreamer may spend time examining and admiring the perceptual environment and the way it appears to imitate that of waking life.See Green, C. (1968). ''Lucid Dreams.'' London: Hamish Hamilton, for examples. Lucid dreams by definition occur during sleep, but they may be regarded as hallucinatory experiences in the same way as non-lucid dreams of a vivid perceptual nature may be regarded as hallucinatory, that is they are examples of 'an experience having the character of sense perception, but without relevant or adequate sensory stimulation […]' Drever, (1952). ''A Dictionary of Psychology''. London: Penguin. ====False awakenings==== A [[false awakening]] is one in which the subject believes he/she has woken up, whether from a lucid or a non-lucid dream, but is in fact still asleep.Cf. Green C. and McCreery C. (1994). ''Lucid Dreaming: the Paradox of Consciousness During Sleep''. London: Routledge. Chapter 7. Sometimes the experience is so realistic perceptually (the sleeper seeming to wake in his or her own bedroom, for example) that insight is not achieved at once, or even until the dreamer really wakes up and realises that what has occurred was hallucinatory. Such experiences seem particularly liable to occur to those who deliberately cultivate lucid dreams. However, they may also occur spontaneously and be associated with the experience of [[sleep paralysis]]. ===Laboratory-induced hallucinations=== Psychotic-like symptoms, such as hallucinations and unusual perceptual experience, involve gross alterations in the experience of reality. Normal perception is substantially constructive and what we perceive is strongly influenced by our prior experiences and expectancies. Healthy individuals prone to hallucinations, or scoring highly on psychometric measures of positive [[schizotypy]], tend to show a bias toward reporting stimuli that did not occur under perceptually ambiguous experimental conditions.Bentall R.P, & Slade P.D. (1985). Reality testing and auditory hallucinations: a signal detection analysis. ''British Journal of Clinical Psychology'', '''24''', 159 –169.Tsakanikos, E. & Reed, P. (2005). Seeing words that are not there: detection biases in psychometric schizotypy. ''British Journal of Clinical Psychology'', '''44''', 295-299 During visual detection of fast-moving words, undergraduate students scoring highly on positive schizotypy had significantly high rates of false perceptions of words (i.e. reported seeing words that were not included in the experimental trials).Tsakanikos, E. & Reed, P. (2005). Do positive schizotypal symptoms predict false perceptual experiences in non-clinical population? ''Journal of Nervous and Mental Disease'', '''193''', 809-812. Positive schizotypal symptoms in healthy adults seem to predict false perceptions in laboratory tasks and certain environmental parameters such as perceptual loadTsakanikos, E. (2006). Perceptual biases and positive schizotypy: the role of perceptual load. ''Personality and Individual Differences'', '''41''', 951-958. and frequency of visual targets Reed, P., Wakefield, D., Harris, J., Parry, J., Cella, M. & Tsakanikos, E. (2008). Seeing non-existing events: effects of environmental conditions, schizotypal symptoms and sub-clinical characteristics. ''Journal of Behavior Therapy & Experimental Psychiatry'', '''39''', 276-291. are critical in the generation of false perceptions. When detection of events becomes either effortless or [[Attention#Influence of Processing Load|cognitively demanding]], generation of such biases can be prevented.Tsakanikos, E. (2006). Perceptual biases and positive schizotypy: the role of perceptual load. ''Personality and Individual Differences'', '''41''', 951-958. ==Subtypes== ===Auditory hallucinations=== {{Main|Auditory hallucinations}} Auditory hallucinations, and in particular the hearing of a voice, are thought of as particularly characteristic of people suffering from [[schizophrenia]]. However, normal subjects also report auditory hallucinations to a surprising extent. For example, Bentall and SladeBentall R.P. and Slade P.D. (1985). Reliability of a scale measuring disposition towards hallucination: a brief report. ''Personality and Individual Differences'', '''6''', 527 529. found that as many as 15.4% of a population of 150 male students were prepared to endorse the statement ‘In the past I have had the experience of hearing a person’s voice and then found that no one was there’. They add:
‘[…]no less than 17.5% of the [subjects] were prepared to score the item “I often hear a voice speaking my thoughts aloud” as “Certainly Applies”. This latter item is usually regarded as a first-rank symptom of schizophrenia[…]’
Green and McCreeryGreen and McCreery, ''Apparitions'', ''op.cit. '' p.85. found that 14% of their 1800 self-selected subjects reported a purely auditory hallucination, and of these nearly half involved the hearing of articulate or inarticulate human speech sounds. An example of the former would be the case of an engineer facing a difficult professional decision, who, while sitting in a cinema, heard a voice saying, ‘loudly and distinctly’: ‘You can’t do it, you know’. He adds:
‘It was so clear and resonant that I turned and looked at my companion who was gazing placidly at the screen[…] I was amazed and somewhat relieved when it became apparent that I was the only person who had heard anything.’''Apparitions'', pp. 85-86.
This case would be an example of what Posey and LoschPosey, T.B. and Losch, M.E. (1983). Auditory hallucinations of hearing voices in 375 normal subjects. ''Imagination, Cognition and Personality'', '''3''', 99-113. call ‘hearing a comforting or advising voice that is not perceived as being one’s own thoughts’. They estimated that approximately 10% of their population of 375 American college students had this type of experience. It has been suggested that auditory hallucinations are affected by culture, to the extent that when American subjects were examined they reported hearing stern authoritarian voices with violent or prohibitive suggestions, whereas voices heard in India and Africa tended to be playful and collaborative instead.{{citation needed|date=November 2017}} ===Sense of presence=== This is a paradoxical experience in which the person has a strong feeling of the presence of another person, sometimes recognised, sometimes unrecognised, but without any apparently justifying sensory stimulus. The nineteenth-century American psychologist and philosopher [[William James]] described the experience thus:
'From the way in which this experience is spoken of by those who have had it, it would appear to be an extremely definite and positive state of mind, coupled with a belief in the reality of its object quite as strong as any direct sensation ever gives. And yet no sensation seems to be connected with it at all... The phenomenon would seem to be due to a pure conception becoming saturated with the sort of stinging urgency which ordinarily only sensations bring.'*James, W. (1890; 1950). ''Principles of Psychology'', Volume II. New York, Dover Publications, pp. 322-3.
The following is an example of this type of experience:
‘My husband died in June 1945, and 26 years afterwards when I was at Church, I felt him standing beside me during the singing of a hymn. I felt I would see him if I turned my head. The feeling was so strong I was reduced to tears. I had not been thinking of him before I felt his presence. I had not had this feeling before that day, neither has it happened since then.’Green and McCreery, ''Apparitions'', ''op.cit''., p.118.
Experiences of this kind appear to meet all but one of the normal criteria of hallucination. For example, Slade and Bentall proposed the following working definition of a hallucination:
‘Any percept-like experience which (a) occurs in the absence of an appropriate stimulus, (b) has the full force or impact of the corresponding actual (real) perception, and (c) is not amenable to direct and voluntary control by the experiencer.’Slade and Bentall, op.cit., p.23.
The experience quoted above certainly meets the second and third of these three criteria. One might add that the ‘presence’ in such a case is experienced as located in a definite position in external physical space. In this respect it may be said to be more hallucinatory than, for example, some [[hypnagogic imagery]], which may be experienced as external to the subject but located in a mental ‘space’ of its own. Leaning, F.E. (1925). An introductory study of hypnagogic phenomena. ''Proceedings of the Society for Psychical Research'', '''35''', 289-409. Mavromatis, A. (1987). ''Hypnagogia: the Unique State of Consciousness Between Wakefulness and Sleep''. London: Routledge and Kegan Paul. Other explanations for this phenomenon were discussed by the psychologist [[Graham Reed (psychologist)|Graham Reed]] who wrote that such experiences may involve [[illusion]], misinterpretation or [[suggestion]]. He noted that the experiences are usually reported at moments of fatigue, stress, or during the night.[[Graham Reed (psychologist)|Reed, Graham]]. (1988). ''The Psychology of Anomalous Experience''. Prometheus Books. pp. 44-45. {{ISBN|0-87975-435-4}} ===Sense of presence experiences in bereavement=== The experience of sensing the presence of a deceased loved one is a commonly reported phenomenon in [[Grief|bereavement]]. It can take the form of a clearly sensory impression or can involve a quasi-sensory 'feeling' of presence. Rees Rees, W.D. (1971). The hallucinations of widowhood. ''[[British Medical Journal]]'', '''4''', 37-41. conducted a study of 293 [[widow]]ed people living in a particular area of mid-[[Wales]]. He found that 14% of those interviewed reported having had a visual hallucination of their deceased [[Marriage|spouse]], 13.3% an auditory one and 2.7% a tactile one. These categories overlapped to some extent as some people reported a hallucinatory experience in more than one modality. Of interest in light of the previous heading was the fact that 46.7% of the sample reported experiencing the presence of the deceased spouse. Other studies have similarly reported a frequency of approximately 50% in the bereaved population. Datson, S.L., & Marwit, S.J. (1997). Personality constructs and perceived presence of deceased loved ones. ''[[Death Studies]]'', '''21''', 131-146. Olson, P.R., Suddeth, J.A., Peterson, P.A., & Egelhoff, C. (1985). Hallucinations of widowhood. ''Journal of the American Geriatric Society'', "33", 543-547. Sensing the presence of the deceased may be a cross-cultural phenomenon that is, however, interpreted differently depending on the cultural context in which it occurs. Steffen, E., & Coyle, A. (2012). 'Sense of presence' experiences in bereavement and their relationship to mental health: A critical examination of a continuing controversy. In C. Murray (Ed.). ''Mental health and anomalous experience'', New York: Nova Science Publishers. For example, one of the earliest studies of the phenomenon published in a Western peer-reviewed journal investigated the [[grief]] experiences of Japanese widows and found that 90% of them reported to have sensed the deceased. Yamamoto, J., Okonogi, K., I wasaki, T., & Yoshimura, S. (1969). Mourning in Japan. ''[[American Journal of Psychiatry]]'', '''125''', 1660-1665. It was observed that, in contrast to Western interpretations, the widows were not concerned about their sanity and made sense of the experience in religious terms. In the Western world, much of the bereavement literature of the 20th century had been influenced by psychoanalytic thinking and viewed these experiences as a form of denial, in the tradition of [[Freud]]'s interpretation in ''Mourning and Melancholia'' of the bereaved person as 'clinging to the object through the medium of a hallucinatory wishful psychosis'. Freud, S. (1917). Mourning and melancholia. In J. [[Strachey]] (Ed. and Trans.). ''The standard edition of the complete psychological works of Sigmund Freud (Vol. XIV)'' (pp. 252-268). London: Hogarth Press. In recent decades, building on cross-cultural evidence about the adaptiveness of such experiences, the continuing bonds perspective as originated by Klass et al. (1996) Klass, D., Silverman, P.R., & Nickman, S. (Eds.). (1996). ''Continuing bonds: New understandings of grief.'' Bristol: Taylor & Francis. has suggested that such experiences can be seen as normal and potentially adaptive in a Western context too. Since then, a number of qualitative studies have been published, describing the mainly beneficial effects of these experiences, especially when they are made sense of in spiritual or religious ways Kwilecki, S. (2011). Ghosts, meaning, and faith: After-death communications in bereavement narratives. ''[[Death Studies]]", '''35''', 219-243. Steffen, E., & Coyle, A. (2011). Sense of presence experiences and meaning-making in bereavement: A qualitative analysis.''[[Death Studies]]'', '''35''', 579-609. While most of these experiences tend to be reported as comforting to the perceiver, a small percentage of people have reported disturbing experiences, and there is ongoing research, for example by Field and others, Field, N.P., & Filanosky, C. (2010). Continuing bonds, risk factors for complicated grief, and adjustment to bereavement. ''[[Death Studies]]'', '''34''', 1-29. to determine when continuing bonds experiences serve adjustment to bereavement and when they may be detrimental. == Theoretical implications == ===Psychological=== The main importance of anomalous experiences such as benign hallucinations to theoretical psychology lies in their relevance to the debate between the disease model versus the dimensional model of [[psychosis]]. According to the disease model, psychotic states such as those associated with [[schizophrenia]] and [[manic-depression]], represent symptoms of an underlying disease process, which is dichotomous in nature; i.e. a given subject either does or does not have the disease, just as a person either does or does not have a physical disease such as tuberculosis. According to the dimensional model, by contrast, the population at large is ranged along a normally distributed continuum or dimension, which has been variously labelled as psychoticism ([[Eysenck|H.J.Eysenck]]), [[schizotypy]] ([[Gordon Claridge]]) or psychosis-proneness.For a discussion of the concept of schizotypy and its variants, cf. McCreery, C. and Claridge, G. (2002). Healthy schizotypy: the case of out-of-the-body experiences. ''Personality and Individual Differences'', '''32''', 141-154. The occurrence of spontaneous hallucinatory experiences in persons who are enjoying good physical health at the time, and who are not drugged or in other unusual physical states of a transient nature such as extreme fatigue, would appear to provide support for the dimensional model.Berrios G E (2005) On Fantastic Apparitions of Vision and Johannes Müller. ''History of Psychiatry'' 16: 229-246. The alternative to this view requires one to posit some hidden or latent disease process, of which such experiences are a symptom or precursor, an explanation which would appear to beg the question. ===Philosophical=== The "argument from hallucination" has traditionally been one of those used by proponents of the philosophical theory of [[Direct and indirect realism|representationalism against direct realism]]. Representationalism holds that when perceiving the world we are not in direct contact with it, as common sense suggests, but only in direct contact with a representation of the world in consciousness. That representation may be a more or less accurate one depending on our circumstances, the state of our health, and so on. Direct realism, on the other hand, holds that the common sense or unthinking view of perception is correct, and that when perceiving the world we should be regarded as in direct contact with it, unmediated by any representation in consciousness. Clearly, during an apparitional experience, for example, the correspondence between how the subject is perceiving the world and how the world really is at that moment is distinctly imperfect. At the same time the experience may present itself to the subject as indistinguishable from normal perception. McCreeryMcCreery, C. (2006). "Perception and Hallucination: the Case for Continuity." ''Philosophical Paper No. 2006-1''. Oxford: Oxford Forum. [http://www.celiagreen.com/charlesmccreery/perception.pdf Online PDF] has argued that such empirical phenomena strengthen the case for representationalism as against direct realism. == See also == *[[Aura (symptom)]] *[[Lucid dream]] *[[False awakening]] *[[Out-of-body experience]] *[[Apparitional experience]] *[[Schizotypy]] *[[Perception]] *[[Philosophy of perception]] *[[Representationalism]] *[[Trance]] *[[Tulpa]] *[[Simulated reality]] *[[Idealism]] == References == {{Reflist|colwidth=30em}} == Further reading == * Aleman, A & Laroi, F. (2008). ''Hallucinations: The Science of Idiosyncratic Perception''. Washington: American Psychological Association. * Birchwood, Max J., Chadwick, Paul, and Trower, Peter (1996). ''Cognitive Therapy for Delusions, Voices and Paranoia.'' New York: John Wiley & Sons Inc. * Cardeña, E., Lynn, S. J., & Krippner, S. (2000). ''Varieties of Anomalous Experience: Examining the Scientific Evidence.'' American Psychological Association. * Johnson, Fred H., (1978). ''The Anatomy of Hallucinations''. Chicago: Nelson-Hall. * Murray, C. (Ed.) (2012). ''Mental Health and Anomalous Experience.'' New York: Nova Science Publishers. * Pearson, R. S. (2005) ''The Experience of Hallucinations in Religious Practice''. Seattle: Telical Books. * Reed, Graham. (1988). ''The Psychology of Anomalous Experience''. {{more footnotes|date=March 2013}} [[File:Sphere wireframe.svg|thumb|In [[Euclidean space]], a '''ball''' is the volume bounded by a sphere]]
In [[mathematics]], a '''ball''' is the space bounded by a [[sphere]]. It may be a '''closed ball''' (including the [[boundary points]] that constitute the sphere) or an '''open ball''' (excluding them).
These concepts are defined not only in three-dimensional [[Euclidean space]] but also for lower and higher dimensions, and for [[metric space]]s in general. A ''ball'' or '''hyperball''' in {{mvar|n}} dimensions is called an '''{{mvar|n}}-ball''' and is bounded by an [[N-sphere|'''({{math|''n'' − 1}})-sphere''']]. Thus, for example, a ball in the [[Euclidean plane]] is the same thing as a [[disk (mathematics)|disk]], the area bounded by a [[circle]]. In [[Euclidean space|Euclidean 3-space]], a ball is taken to be the [[volume]] bounded by a [[2-sphere|2-dimensional sphere]]. In a [[one-dimensional space]], a ball is a [[line segment]].
In other contexts, such as in [[Euclidean geometry]] and informal use, ''sphere'' is sometimes used to mean ''ball''.
==Balls in Euclidean space== In Euclidean {{mvar|n}}-space, an (open) {{mvar|n}}-ball of radius {{mvar|r}} and center {{mvar|x}} is the set of all points of distance less than {{mvar|r}} from {{mvar|x}}. A closed {{mvar|n}}-ball of radius {{mvar|r}} is the set of all points of distance less than or equal to {{mvar|r}} away from {{mvar|x}}.
In Euclidean {{mvar|n}}-space, every ball is bounded by a [[hypersphere]]. The ball is a bounded [[Interval (mathematics)|interval]] when {{math|1=''n'' = 1}}, is a '''[[Disk (mathematics)|disk]]''' bounded by a [[circle]] when {{math|1=''n'' = 2}}, and is bounded by a [[sphere]] when {{math|1=''n'' = 3}}.
=== Volume === {{main article|Volume of an n-ball|l1=Volume of an {{mvar|n}}-ball}} The {{mvar|n}}-dimensional volume of a Euclidean ball of radius {{mvar|R}} in {{mvar|n}}-dimensional Euclidean space is:<ref>Equation 5.19.4, ''NIST Digital Library of Mathematical Functions.'' http://dlmf.nist.gov/,{{dead link|date=July 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} Release 1.0.6 of 2013-05-06.</ref> :<math>V_n(R) = \frac{\pi^\frac{n}{2}}{\Gamma\left(\frac{n}{2} + 1\right)}R^n,</math> where {{math|Γ}} is [[Leonhard Euler]]'s [[gamma function]] (which can be thought of as an extension of the [[factorial]] function to fractional arguments). Using explicit formulas for [[particular values of the gamma function]] at the integers and half integers gives formulas for the volume of a Euclidean ball that do not require an evaluation of the gamma function. These are: :<math>\begin{align}V_{2k}(R) &= \frac{\pi^k}{k!}R^{2k}\,,\\ V_{2k+1}(R) &= \frac{2^{k+1}\pi^k}{(2k+1)!!}R^{2k+1} = \frac{2(k!)(4\pi)^k}{(2k+1)!}R^{2k+1}\,.\end{align}</math> In the formula for odd-dimensional volumes, the [[double factorial]] {{math|(2''k'' + 1)!!}} is defined for odd integers {{math|2''k'' + 1}} as {{math|1=(2''k'' + 1)!! = 1 · 3 · 5 · … · (2''k'' − 1) · (2''k'' + 1)}}.
==Balls in general metric spaces== Let {{math|(''M'', ''d'')}} be a [[metric space]], namely a set {{mvar|M}} with a [[Metric (mathematics)|metric]] (distance function) {{mvar|d}}. The open (metric) '''ball of radius''' {{math|''r'' > 0}} centered at a point {{mvar|p}} in {{mvar|M}}, usually denoted by {{math|''B<sub>r</sub>''(''p'')}} or {{math|''B''(''p''; ''r'')}}, is defined by
:<math>B_r(p) = \{ x \in M \mid d(x,p) < r \},</math>
The closed (metric) ball, which may be denoted by {{math|''B<sub>r</sub>''[''p'']}} or {{math|''B''[''p''; ''r'']}}, is defined by
:<math>B_r[p] = \{ x \in M \mid d(x,p) \le r \}.</math>
Note in particular that a ball (open or closed) always includes {{mvar|p}} itself, since the definition requires {{math|''r'' > 0}}.
The [[closure (mathematics)|closure]] of the open ball {{math|''B<sub>r</sub>''(''p'')}} is usually denoted {{math|{{overline|''B<sub>r</sub>''(''p'')}}}}. While it is always the case that {{math|''B<sub>r</sub>''(''p'') ⊆ {{overline|''B<sub>r</sub>''(''p'')}} ⊆ ''B<sub>r</sub>''[''p'']}}, it is {{em|not}} always the case that {{math|{{overline|''B<sub>r</sub>''(''p'')}} {{=}} ''B<sub>r</sub>''[''p'']}}. For example, in a metric space {{mvar|X}} with the [[discrete metric]], one has {{math|{{overline|''B''<sub>1</sub>(''p'')}} {{=}} {p<nowiki>}</nowiki>}} and {{math|''B''<sub>1</sub>[''p''] {{=}} ''X''}}, for any {{math|''p'' ∈ ''X''}}.
A '''[[unit ball]]''' (open or closed) is a ball of radius 1.
A subset of a metric space is [[bounded set|bounded]] if it is contained in some ball. A set is [[totally bounded]] if, given any positive radius, it is covered by finitely many balls of that radius.
The open balls of a [[metric space]] can serve as a [[base (topology)|base]], giving this space a [[topological space|topology]], the open sets of which are all possible [[union (set theory)|union]]s of open balls. This topology on a metric space is called the '''topology induced by''' the metric {{mvar|d}}.
==Balls in normed vector spaces== Any [[normed vector space]] {{mvar|V}} with norm <math>\|\cdot\|</math> is also a metric space with the metric <math>d (x,y)= \|x-y\|.</math> In such spaces, an arbitrary ball <math>B_r(y)</math> of points <math>x</math> around a point <math>y</math> with a distance of less than <math>r</math> may be viewed as a scaled (by <math>r</math>) and translated (by <math>y</math>) copy of a ''unit ball'' <math>B_1(0).</math> Such "centered" balls with <math>y=0</math> are denoted with <math>B(r).</math>
The Euclidean balls discussed earlier are an example of balls in a normed vector space.
==={{mvar|p}}-norm=== In a [[Cartesian space]] {{math|ℝ<sup>''n''</sup>}} with the [[p-norm|{{mvar|p}}-norm]] {{mvar|L<sub>p</sub>}}, that is
:<math>\left\| x \right\| _p = \left( |x_1|^p + |x_2|^p + \dotsb + |x_n|^p \right) ^{1/p},</math>
an open ball around the origin with radius <math>r</math> is given by the set
:<math> B(r) = \left\{ x \in \R^n \,:\left\| x \right\| _p = \left( |x_1|^p + |x_2|^p + \dotsb + |x_n|^p \right) ^{1/p} < r \right\}.</math>
For {{math|1=''n'' = 2}}, in a 2-dimensional plane <math>\mathbb R^2</math>, "balls" according to the {{math|''L''<sub>1</sub>}}-norm (often called the ''[[Taxicab geometry|taxicab]]'' or ''Manhattan'' metric) are bounded by squares with their ''diagonals'' parallel to the coordinate axes; those according to the {{math|''L''<sub>∞</sub>}}-norm, also called the [[Chebyshev distance|Chebyshev]] metric, have squares with their ''sides'' parallel to the coordinate axes as their boundaries. The {{math|''L''<sub>2</sub>}}-norm, known as the Euclidean metric, generates the well known discs within circles, and for other values of {{mvar|p}}, the corresponding balls are areas bounded by [[Lamé curve]]s (hypoellipses or hyperellipses).
For {{math|1=''n'' = 3}}, the {{math|''L''<sub>1</sub>}}- balls are within octahedra with axes-aligned ''body diagonals'', the {{math|''L''<sub>∞</sub>}}-balls are within cubes with axes-aligned ''edges'', and the boundaries of balls for {{mvar|L<sub>p</sub>}} with {{math|''p'' > 2}} are [[superegg|superellipsoids]]. Obviously, {{math|''p'' {{=}} 2}} generates the inner of usual spheres.
===General convex norm=== More generally, given any [[central symmetry|centrally symmetric]], [[bounded set|bounded]], [[open set|open]], and [[convex set|convex]] subset {{mvar|X}} of {{math|ℝ<sup>''n''</sup>}}, one can define a [[Norm (mathematics)|norm]] on {{math|ℝ<sup>''n''</sup>}} where the balls are all translated and uniformly scaled copies of {{mvar|X}}. Note this theorem does not hold if "open" subset is replaced by "closed" subset, because the origin point qualifies but does not define a norm on {{math|ℝ<sup>''n''</sup>}}.
==Topological balls==
One may talk about balls in any [[topological space]] {{mvar|X}}, not necessarily induced by a metric. An (open or closed) {{mvar|n}}-dimensional '''topological ball''' of {{mvar|X}} is any subset of {{mvar|X}} which is [[homeomorphic]] to an (open or closed) Euclidean {{mvar|n}}-ball. Topological {{mvar|n}}-balls are important in [[combinatorial topology]], as the building blocks of [[cell complex]]es.
Any open topological {{mvar|n}}-ball is homeomorphic to the Cartesian space {{math|ℝ<sup>''n''</sup>}} and to the open [[hypercube|unit {{mvar|n}}-cube]] (hypercube) {{math|(0, 1)<sup>''n''</sup> ⊆ ℝ<sup>''n''</sup>}}. Any closed topological {{mvar|n}}-ball is homeomorphic to the closed {{mvar|n}}-cube {{math|[0, 1]<sup>''n''</sup>}}.
An {{mvar|n}}-ball is homeomorphic to an {{mvar|m}}-ball if and only if {{math|1=''n'' = ''m''}}. The homeomorphisms between an open {{mvar|n}}-ball {{mvar|B}} and {{math|ℝ<sup>''n''</sup>}} can be classified in two classes, that can be identified with the two possible [[orientation (mathematics)|topological orientation]]s of {{mvar|B}}.
A topological {{mvar|n}}-ball need not be [[differentiable manifold|smooth]]; if it is smooth, it need not be [[diffeomorphic]] to a Euclidean {{mvar|n}}-ball.

S. |last=Dowker |journal=[[Classical and Quantum Gravity]] |year=1996 |volume=13 |issue=4 |pages=585–610 |doi=10.1088/0264-9381/13/4/003 |arxiv=hep-th/9506042 |bibcode=1996CQGra..13..585D }} * {{cite journal |first=Peter M. |last=Gruber |title=Isometries of the space of convex bodies contained in a Euclidean ball |journal=[[Israel Journal of Mathematics]] |year=1982 |volume=42 |issue=4 |pages=277–283 |doi=10.1007/BF02761407 }}

{{EngvarB|date=October 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=October 2014}} {{Infobox Civil Conflict | title =Bersih 2.0 rally | partof = [[Bersih rally (disambiguation)|Bersih rally]] | image = [[File:Bersih 2.0 logo.png|200px]] | caption = Bersih 2.0 logo | date = 9 July 2011 | place = [[Kuala Lumpur]], Malaysia | coordinates = | causes = | status = Concluded | goals = To call for free and fair elections in Malaysia. | methods = | side1 = [[Bersih]]
[[Pakatan Rakyat]] | side2 = [[United Malays National Organisation]] (UMNO) Youth Wing | leadfigures1 = [[Ambiga Sreenevasan]]
[[A. Samad Said]] | leadfigures2 = [[Khairy Jamaluddin]] | leadfigures3 = | howmany1 = 10,000 to over 20,000
(50,000 claimed by Bersih,
6,000 claimed by police) | howmany2 = 500{{cite news|last=Flitton|first=Daniel|title=Anwar tells of riot squad ambush|url=http://www.smh.com.au/world/anwar-tells-of-riot-squad-ambush-20110711-1had7.html|accessdate=11 July 2011|newspaper=Sydney Morning Herald|date=11 July 2011}}{{cite news |title=Umno Youth's Patriot rally fizzles out in the rain |url=http://www.malaysiakini.com/news/169428 |work=[[Malaysiakini]] |date=9 July 2011 |last=Lee |first=Regina |accessdate=9 July 2011}} | howmany3 = | casualties_label = Casualties | casualties1 = 1 death (Heart attack) | casualties2 = | casualties3 = | notes = }} The '''Bersih 2.0 rally''' (also called the '''Walk for Democracy''') was a demonstration in [[Kuala Lumpur]] held on 9 July 2011 as a follow-up to the [[2007 Bersih rally]]. The rally, organised by the Coalition for Clean and Fair Elections ([[Bersih]]), was supported by [[Pakatan Rakyat]], the coalition of the three largest opposition parties in Malaysia, but was deemed illegal by the government. Bersih, chaired by former president of the [[Malaysian Bar|Bar Council]] [[Ambiga Sreenevasan]], were pushing the [[Election Commission of Malaysia]] (EC) to ensure free and fair elections in Malaysia. It demanded that the EC clean up the electoral roll, reform postal voting, use indelible ink, introduce a minimum 21-day campaign period, allow all parties free access to the media, and put an end to electoral fraud. The [[Royal Malaysia Police|police]] vowed to stop any rallies from taking place on the planned date on the grounds that all public gatherings without police permits are illegal. Having originally planned to march through the streets of Kuala Lumpur, Bersih decided to hold its rally at [[Stadium Merdeka|Merdeka Stadium]] after consultations with the [[Yang di-Pertuan Agong]], Malaysia's head of state. Supporters of Bersih claim that demands for electoral reform made during the 2007 demonstration fell on deaf ears. [[United Malays National Organisation|UMNO]] Youth and [[Perkasa]] planned counter-rallies, dismissing Bersih's demands for electoral reform, but Perkasa called off its counter-rally due to its inability to secure a venue and permit. Estimates of the turnout ranged between 10,000 and over 20,000. The protestors were unable to congregate at Merdeka Stadium as many were forced to disperse by police who were heavily deployed throughout the city. Police arrested more than 1600 protestors, including [[Ambiga Sreenevasan|Ambiga]] and several opposition figures. ==Background== The ruling coalition in Malaysia, [[Barisan Nasional]] (BN), which consists of parties representing the major racial groups in Malaysia, has won every federal election since independence in 1957.{{cite news |title=Malaysia set for general election |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/asia-pacific/7283239.stm |work=BBC News |date=7 March 2008 |accessdate=20 June 2011}} Opposition parties and civil society organisations have long claimed that BN has been manipulating elections in its favour. [[Pan-Malaysian Islamic Party]] (PAS) deputy president [[Mohamad Sabu]] said there were many "concerns" about how the [[Next Malaysian general election|next general election]] will be conducted. He accused BN of cheating tactics, including registering foreign nationals as BN voters.{{cite news |title=Mat Sabu: Make Bersih rally a success |url=http://www.freemalaysiatoday.com/2011/06/05/mat-sabu-make-bersih-rally-a-success/ |work=Free Malaysia Today |date=5 June 2011 |author=Tarani Palani |accessdate=13 June 2011}} PAS information chief Tuan Ibrahim Tuan Man said the EC and the National Registration Department (NRD) "were committing abuses," and that there were "rampant media abuses."{{cite news |title=Bersih: PAS repeats call for police to act on UMNO-Perkasa |url=http://en.harakahdaily.net/index.php/berita-utama/2965-bersih-pas-repeats-call-for-police-to-act-on-umno-perkasa.html |work=Harakah Daily |date=15 June 2011 |accessdate=16 June 2011}} [[Democratic Action Party]] (DAP) member of parliament [[Teresa Kok]] accused BN of "gerrymandering" and "malapportioning" electoral constituencies.{{cite news |title=DAP pledges support for Bersih rally |url=http://www.themalaysianinsider.com/malaysia/article/dap-pledges-support-for-bersih-rally/ |work=[[The Malaysian Insider]] |date=14 June 2011 |last=Chi |first=Melissa |accessdate=14 June 2011}} She also pointed out how the opposition parties' share of seats in parliament was a lot less than their share of the popular vote. Leader of the Opposition [[Anwar Ibrahim]] claimed that BN would lose power if elections were free and fair.{{cite news |title=Umno fears losing power in fair polls, says Anwar |url=http://www2.themalaysianinsider.com/malaysia/article/umno-fears-losing-power-in-fair-polls-says-anwar |work=[[The Malaysian Insider]] |date=12 June 2011 |last=Boo |first=Su-Lyn |accessdate=21 June 2011}} Civil society organisation Aliran claimed that there are "severe restrictions on political freedom" on opposition politicians in Malaysia.{{cite web |title=The Electoral Process |url=http://www.aliran.com/oldsite/hr/js9.html |publisher=Aliran |accessdate=21 June 2011}} It highlighted structural problems such as access to the media, short notices of election dates, and short campaign periods.{{cite web |title=Elections: BN no longer has the upper hand! |url=http://aliran.com/1363.html |publisher=Aliran |date=2 August 2010 |accessdate=20 June 2011}} Human rights group [[SUARAM]] also claim abuses by the ruling party such as [[gerrymandering]] constituencies, using public funds for projects to win political support, and the "unscrutinised" counting of [[postal ballot]]s. [[Transparency International]]'s Malaysian branch, criticising both BN and opposition parties, spoke out against financial rewards promised by political parties to voters while campaigning, calling the practice "vote buying" and "corrupt."{{cite news |title=Election handouts are bribes, says Transparency International |url=http://www.themalaysianinsider.com/malaysia/article/election-handouts-are-bribes-says-transparency-international/ |work=[[The Malaysian Insider]] |date=30 March 2011 |author=Shazwan Mustafa Kamal |accessdate=21 June 2011}} Both the Election Commission and BN have denied allegations of abuse.{{cite news |title=Proses pilihan raya di Malaysia adil, setanding negara lain, kata Nazri |url=http://www.themalaysianinsider.com/bahasa/article/proses-pilihan-raya-di-malaysia-adil-setanding-negara-lain-kata-nazri/ |work=[[The Malaysian Insider]] |language=Malay |date=8 March 2011 |accessdate=21 June 2011}}{{cite news |title=Malaysia to fingerprint voters to combat fraud |url=https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5hdhLXlCP4BzAtxTuathX5zi2R01A?docId=CNG.963a0e763934a3c0cbab82fe6f730a60.481 |author=AFP |authorlink=Agence France Presse |date=21 June 2011 |accessdate=21 June 2011}}{{cite news |title=Malaysia arrests 14 for 'Bersih' protest T-shirts |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2011/jun/29/malaysia-arrests-bersih-t-shirts |work=The Guardian |location=UK |agency=Associated Press |authorlink=Associated Press |date=29 June 2011 |accessdate=30 June 2011}} ===Protests in Malaysia=== Street demonstrations are rare in Malaysia, but the public has become more vocal with the rise of alternative media and a resurgent opposition.{{cite news |title=Malaysia police lock down capital ahead of protest |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2011/07/09/us-malaysia-protest-idUSTRE7680B720110709 |agency=Reuters |date=9 July 2011 |author1=Niluksi Koswanage |author2=Razak Ahmad |accessdate=9 July 2011}} Gatherings in Malaysia of five or more people must receive a police permit, which is rarely granted. The government has used heavy police presence to block rallies as well as arrest protest leaders to stop illegal public protests. Former prime minister [[Abdullah Ahmad Badawi]] said he was willing to sacrifice public freedoms in the interest of national stability.{{cite news |title=Malaysia PM 'will defend stability' |url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/asia-pacific/2007/12/2008525142537935531.html |publisher=Al Jazeera English |date=10 December 2007 |accessdate=20 June 2011}} Four rallies in 2007 ended with arrests made by police. A protest in 2009 against the [[Internal Security Act (Malaysia)|Internal Security Act]] was also broken up by tear gas and water cannons.{{cite news |title=Malaysia protest march broken up |url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/asia-pacific/2009/08/20098174920522755.html |publisher=Al Jazeera English |date=1 August 2009 |accessdate=20 June 2011}} ===Bersih=== [[File:20071110Bersih2Hafiz.jpg|thumb|300px|A scene from the 2007 rally. Protestors on the left are dressed in yellow. They are met by the [[Federal Reserve Unit]], the riot police (in red helmets). Standing in between the protestors and the riot police are PAS's Jabatan Amal volunteer unit (dressed in maroon).]] [[Bersih]], short for the Coalition for Clean and Fair Elections ({{lang-ms|Gabungan Pilihanraya '''Bersih''' dan Adil}}), is a coalition of 62 non-governmental organisations founded in November 2006.{{cite web |title=Endorsees |url=http://bersih.org/?page_id=360 |publisher=Bersih |accessdate=14 June 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120408101727/http://bersih.org/?page_id=360 |archivedate=8 April 2012 |df=dmy-all }}{{cite web |title=About BERSIH |url=http://bersih.org/?page_id=352 |publisher=Bersih |accessdate=21 June 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110622172238/http://bersih.org/?page_id=352 |archivedate=22 June 2011 |df=dmy-all }} Since its founding, Bersih has been supported by the three main opposition parties, [[Parti Keadilan Rakyat]] (PKR), PAS, and DAP. ''Bersih'' is the Malay word for "clean"{{cite web |title=Bersih |url=http://prpm.dbp.gov.my/Search.aspx?k=bersih |work=Dictionary |publisher=Dewan Bahasa dan Pustaka |accessdate=21 June 2011}} in reference to the claims of large scale corruption in the leading party. The [[2007 Bersih rally|first Bersih rally]] on 10 November 2007 was estimated to have drawn between 30,000 and 50,000 people.{{cite news |title=Police block Malaysia protest |url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/asia-pacific/2007/12/2008525131234195960.html |publisher=Al Jazeera English |date=22 December 2007 |accessdate=20 June 2011}} It was broken up by police using [[tear gas]] and chemical-laced [[water cannon]]s.{{cite news |title=Malaysia police break up protest |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/7088877.stm |work=BBC News |date=10 November 2007 |last=Brant |first=Robin |accessdate=20 June 2011}} The rally was said to play a major role in helping the opposition parties make big gains in the [[Malaysian general election, 2008|2008 general election]].{{cite news |title=Malaysian politics take to the streets |url=http://www.atimes.com/atimes/Southeast_Asia/MF24Ae02.html |work=[[Asia Times Online]] |date=24 June 2011 |last=Netto |first=Anil |accessdate=26 June 2011}} Bersih 2.0, as the organisation branded itself for the 2011 rally, is chaired by former [[Malaysian Bar|Bar Council]] president [[Ambiga Sreenevasan]]. Ambiga served as president of the Bar from 2007 to 2009 and is a recipient of the [[United States Department of State|US State Department]]'s International Women of Courage Awards.{{cite web |title=Presidents' Roll |url=http://www.malaysianbar.org.my/past_presidents.html |publisher=Malaysian Bar |accessdate=21 June 2011 }}{{cite web |title=Remarks by Clinton on International Women of Courage Awards |url=http://www.america.gov/st/texttrans-english/2009/March/20090312132025xjsnommis0.1997949.html&distid=ucs#ixzz1PtAnEl7f |publisher=U.S. Department of State |date=11 March 2009 |accessdate=21 June 2011 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110228192528/http://www.america.gov/st/texttrans-english/2009/March/20090312132025xjsnommis0.1997949.html%26distid%3Ducs#ixzz1PtAnEl7f |archive-date=28 February 2011 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }} ===Demands=== Ambiga has summed up the main issues raised by the organisation she leads as "unhappiness... in the [[Sarawak state election, 2011|Sarawak [election]]], unhappiness about corruption, [and] unhappiness about the independence of our institutions."{{cite news |title=Bersih rally goes on, says Ambiga, PAS |url=http://www.themalaysianinsider.com/malaysia/article/bersih-rally-goes-on-says-ambiga-pas/ |last=Boo |first=Su-Lyn |work=[[The Malaysian Insider]] |date=12 June 2011 |accessdate=13 June 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110613043850/http://www.themalaysianinsider.com/malaysia/article/bersih-rally-goes-on-says-ambiga-pas |archivedate=13 June 2011 |df=dmy-all }} She said demands made during the first rally in 2007 have not been addressed, hence the follow-up rally.{{cite news |title=Ambiga asks politicians to join Bersih rally |url=http://www.themalaysianinsider.com/malaysia/article/ambiga-asks-politicians-to-join-bersih-rally/ |work=[[The Malaysian Insider]] |date=12 June 2011 |last=Boo |first=Su-Lyn |accessdate=13 June 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110613212007/http://www.themalaysianinsider.com/malaysia/article/ambiga-asks-politicians-to-join-bersih-rally/ |archivedate=13 June 2011 |df=dmy-all }} The communiqué issued by Bersih issued in 2007 called for reforms to Malaysia's [[first-past-the-post]] electoral system, ensuring the independence of the [[Election Commission of Malaysia|Election Commission]] (EC), eliminating electoral practices deemed unfair to opposition candidates, eliminating corrupt campaign practices, equal access to the media for all political parties, and instituting a [[caretaker government]] during election periods, among others in the long term.{{cite web |title=Joint Communiqué |url=http://bersih.org/?page_id=115 |publisher=Bersih |date=23 November 2006 (updated July 2007) |accessdate=13 June 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110621011418/http://bersih.org/?page_id=115 |archivedate=21 June 2011 |df=dmy-all }} The 2011 rally's immediate demands were:{{cite web|title=Bersih's 8 demands|url=http://bersih.org/?page_id=4111|publisher=Bersih 2.0|accessdate=12 July 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110714040850/http://bersih.org/?page_id=4111|archivedate=14 July 2011|df=dmy-all}} # Clean the electoral roll # Reform [[postal voting]] # Use of [[indelible ink]] # A minimum [[Political campaign|campaign]] period of 21 days # Free and fair access to [[Media of Malaysia|mainstream media]] # Strengthen public institutions # Stop corruption # Stop dirty politics After agreeing to abandon plans for a street demonstration, Bersih also called for a [[Royal Commission]] into election practices.{{cite news |title=Bersih wants supporters freed, RCI on election practices |url=http://www.themalaysianinsider.com/malaysia/article/bersih-wants-supporters-freed-rci-on-election-practices/ |work=[[The Malaysian Insider]] |date=6 July 2011 |last=Teoh |first=Shannon |accessdate=6 July 2011}} ===Plans=== The rally's original plan was to have protestors gather at the KL Sogo shopping center, [[Kuala Lumpur City Hall]] building, and the [[Kampung Baru Mosque]] before marching to the [[Istana Negara, Jalan Istana|Istana Negara]] to deliver a memorandum to the [[Yang di-Pertuan Agong]]. After consultations with the King, Bersih decided to hold the rally in a stadium instead.{{cite news |title=Malaysia Street Protests Averted as Group Agrees to Use Stadium |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-07-05/malaysia-street-protests-averted-as-group-agrees-to-use-stadium.html |publisher=Bloomberg |date=5 July 2011 |last1=Gan |first1=Yen Kuan |last2=Ten Kate |first2=Daniel |accessdate=5 July 2011}} However, their request to use [[Merdeka Stadium]] was rejected by police.{{cite news |title=Police declines Bersih 2.0 permit application to hold rally at Merdeka Stadium |url=http://www.nst.com.my/nst/articles/PolicedeclinesBersih2_0permitapplicationtoholdrallyatMerdekaStadium/Article/#ixzz1RWMOPfRh |work=[[New Straits Times]] |date=8 July 2011 |accessdate=8 July 2011}} Bersih accused the government of reneging on a previous offer to let them rally in a stadium instead of the streets.{{cite news |title=Government cannot stop us, says Bersih |url=http://www.themalaysianinsider.com/malaysia/article/government-cannot-stop-us-says-bersih/ |work=[[The Malaysian Insider]] |date=8 July 2011 |last=Teoh |first=Shannon |accessdate=8 July 2011}} Bersih insisted on gathering at Merdeka Stadium, despite [[#Lockdown|preventative measures]] taken by police. ====Abroad==== Simultaneous rallies in support of Bersih were planned by Malaysian citizens in more than 30 cities in New Zealand, Australia, Japan, South Korea, the Philippines, Taiwan, Hong Kong, Singapore, Thailand, Indonesia, Egypt, Switzerland, Sweden, Austria, France, [[UK|Great Britain]], Ireland, Canada, the United States and Cambodia.{{cite news |title=Bersih to go global with July 9 rally |url=http://www.themalaysianinsider.com/malaysia/article/bersih-to-go-global-with-july-9-rally |work=[[The Malaysian Insider]] |date=24 June 2011 |author=Shazwan Mustafa Kamal |accessdate=30 June 2011}}{{cite news |title=Asian democracy crusades take root |url=http://www.theaustralian.com.au/news/world/asian-democracy-crusades-take-root/story-e6frg6ux-1226087447434 |work=The Australian |date=5 July 2011 |last=Hoffstaedter |first=Gerhard |accessdate=8 July 2011}}{{cite news |title=Bersih rally goes global |url=http://www.freemalaysiatoday.com/2011/07/07/bersih-rally-goes-global/ |work=Free Malaysia Today |last=Teoh |first=El Sen |date=7 July 2011 |accessdate=8 July 2011}} ==Lead-up to the rally== ===Announcement=== After frustration at by being shut out of [[Election monitoring|observing]] the [[Sarawak state election, 2011|April 2011 Sarawak election]], Bersih announced in a press release on 26 May that it had decided to organise a gathering on 9 July to press for electoral reform.{{cite web |title=Bersih 2.0: Deportation of activist from Sarawak and announcement of ‘Perhimpunan Rakyat’ |url=http://bersih.org/?p=3844 |publisher=Bersih |date=26 May 2011 |accessdate=16 June 2011}} ===Counter-rallies=== ====Perkasa==== [[Ketuanan Melayu|Malay Supremacy]] movement [[Perkasa]] spoke out strongly against the rally.{{cite news |title=Perkasa vows counter-protest against Bersih rally |url=http://www.themalaysianinsider.com/malaysia/article/perkasa-vows-counter-protest-against-bersih-rally/ |work=[[The Malaysian Insider]] |date=13 June 2011 |author=Shazwan Mustafa Kamal |accessdate=13 June 2011}} On 15 June, Perkasa announced that it had secured the support of over 30 non-governmental organisations and challenged Bersih organisers over who could stage a bigger rally on 9 July.{{cite news |title=Let’s see who’s bigger, Perkasa dares Bersih |url=http://www.themalaysianinsider.com/malaysia/article/lets-see-whos-bigger-perkasa-dares-bersih/ |work=[[The Malaysian Insider]] |date=15 June 2011 |last=Teoh |first=Shannon |accessdate=15 June 2011}} It called on Bersih to cancel its rally, warning that clashes might occur. Perkasa president [[Ibrahim Ali (Malaysia)|Ibrahim Ali]] warned "[If they proceed] there will be a clash. If that happens, it is for the better."{{cite news |title=Perkasa ready to counter Bersih rally |url=http://www.freemalaysiakini.com/modules.php?name=News&file=article&sid=14002&mode=thread&order=0&thold=0 |work=Free Malaysiakini |date=13 June 2011 |accessdate=16 June 2011}} On 19 June, Perkasa held a gathering to protest the Bersih rally and to launch an opposing coalition of NGOs known as Gerak Aman.{{cite news |title=Gerak Aman and Bersih 2.0 launch movements on same day |url=http://thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=/2011/6/20/nation/8934868&sec=nation |work=[[The Star (Malaysia)|The Star]] |date=20 June 2011 |accessdate=26 June 2011}} During the gathering, images of Ambiga—described by flyers as "a dangerous Hindu woman"—were burned, while Ibrahim warned the Chinese community not to participate in the Bersih rally.{{cite news |title=Ibrahim raises spectre of May 13 at anti-Bersih rally launch |url=http://www.themalaysianinsider.com/malaysia/article/ibrahim-raises-spectre-of-may 13-at-anti-bersih-rally-launch/ |work=[[The Malaysian Insider]] |date=19 June 2011 |last=Yow |first=Hong Chieh |accessdate=19 June 2011}} On 8 July, Perkasa announced the cancellation of its counter-rally due to its inability to secure a venue and a police permit.{{cite news |title=Perkasa rally in limbo, chief to stay home |url=http://www.freemalaysiatoday.com/2011/07/08/perkasa-rally-in-limbo-chief-to-stay-home/ |work=Free Malaysia Today |date=8 July 2011 |author=Tarani Palani |accessdate=8 July 2011}}{{cite news |title=Perkasa cancels rally, but members to loiter in city |url=http://www.malaysiakini.com/news/169283 |work=[[Malaysiakini]] |date=8 July 2011 |last=Kuek Ser |first=Kuang Keng |accessdate=8 July 2011}} ====UMNO Youth==== [[UMNO]] Youth leader [[Khairy Jamaluddin]] announced that UMNO Youth will hold another rally on the same day (known as the "Patriot Rally" or ''Himpunan Patriot''){{cite news |title=Umno Youth's 'Patriot' Counter-rally Launched |author=Bernama |authorlink=Bernama |date=26 June 2011 |accessdate=26 June 2011 |url=http://www.bernama.com/bernama/v5/newsindex.php?id=596886}} to "strengthen the democratic system" and show that "the voice of the people does not belong only to the opposition."{{cite news |title=Umno Youth to gather on July 9, rival Bersih rally |url=http://www.themalaysianinsider.com/malaysia/article/umno-youth-to-gather-on-july-9-rival-bersih-rally/ |work=[[The Malaysian Insider]] |date=16 June 2011 |accessdate=16 June 2011}}{{cite news |title=Umno Youth to march on July 9 for preserving country's democratic system |url=http://thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=/2011/6/16/nation/20110616192325&sec=nation |work=[[The Star (Malaysia)|The Star]] |date=16 June 2011 |accessdate=16 June 2011}} He added that they had "a right to assembly guaranteed by the constitution."{{cite news |title=Thumbing nose at Hisham, Khairy says march goes on |url=http://www.themalaysianinsider.com/malaysia/article/thumbing-nose-at-hisham-khairy-says-march-goes-on/ |date=17 June 2011 |last=Teoh |first=Shannon |accessdate=17 June 2011}} Khairy and Ibrahim became involved in a war of words over the latter's comments on regarding the Chinese community, with each side calling for the other to be investigated under the [[Sedition Act (Malaysia)|Sedition Act]].{{cite news |title=Ibrahim Ali’s remarks not representative of Malays, says Khairy |url=http://www.themalaysianinsider.com/malaysia/article/ibrahim-alis-remarks-not-representative-of-malays-says-khairy/ |work=[[The Malaysian Insider]] |date=20 June 2011 |author=Shazwan Mustafa Kamal |accessdate=21 June 2011 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110621214257/http://www.themalaysianinsider.com/malaysia/article/ibrahim-alis-remarks-not-representative-of-malays-says-khairy/ |archive-date=21 June 2011 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }}{{cite news |title=Perkasa boss slams ‘old cow’ Kit, ‘rich’ Khairy |url=http://www.freemalaysiatoday.com/2011/06/21/perkasa-boss-slams-old-cow-kit-rich-khairy/ |work=Free Malaysia Today |date=21 June 2011 |author=K Pragalath |accessdate=21 June 2011}}{{cite news |title=Perkasa: KJ juga perlu disiasat bawah ISA |url=http://www.freemalaysiatoday.com/2011/06/21/perkasa-kj-juga-perlu-disiasat-bawah-isa/ |work=Free Malaysia Today |date=21 June 2011 |author=Fazy Sahir |accessdate=21 June 2011}} Ibrahim later backtracked from his comments.{{cite news |title=Ibrahim Ali: I was misunderstood |url=http://www.themalaysianinsider.com/malaysia/article/ibrahim-ali-i-was-misunderstood/ |work=[[The Malaysian Insider]] |date=21 June 2011 |last=Chooi |first=Clara |accessdate=21 June 2011 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110622231105/http://www.themalaysianinsider.com/malaysia/article/ibrahim-ali-i-was-misunderstood/ |archive-date=22 June 2011 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }} UMNO Youth's plan was to gather at [[Bukit Bintang]] and possibly march towards Merdeka Stadium.{{cite news |title=Umno Youth to defy ban, may rally at Stadium Merdeka |url=http://www.freemalaysiatoday.com/2011/07/08/umno-youth-to-defy-ban-may-rally-at-stadium-merdeka/ |work=Free Malaysia Today |date=8 July 2011 |author=Syed Jamal Zahiid |accessdate=8 July 2011}} ===Election Commission reaction=== Bersih's demands were repeatedly dismissed by the [[Election Commission of Malaysia|Election Commission]] (EC), who sought to tie the organisation to the opposition's agenda.{{cite news |title=EC: Bersih intends to overthrow govt |url=http://www.freemalaysiatoday.com/2011/06/30/ec-bersih-intends-to-overthrow-govt/ |work=Free Malaysia Today |date=30 June 2011 |last=Sta Maria |first=Stephanie |accessdate=30 June 2011 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110701100814/http://www.freemalaysiatoday.com/2011/06/30/ec-bersih-intends-to-overthrow-govt/ |archive-date=1 July 2011 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }} EC deputy chairman Wan Ahmad Wan Omar claimed Bersih was working with [[Pakatan Rakyat]] to "overthrow the government." In turn, Ambiga criticised the EC's conduct, asking them to remain independent from politics.{{cite news |title=Ambiga tells EC to remain neutral |url=http://www.themalaysianinsider.com/malaysia/article/ambiga-tells-ec-to-remain-neutral/ |work=[[The Malaysian Insider]] |date=30 June 2011 |last=Yow |first=Hong Chieh |accessdate=30 June 2011 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110701182220/http://www.themalaysianinsider.com/malaysia/article/ambiga-tells-ec-to-remain-neutral/ |archive-date=1 July 2011 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }} On 20 June, the EC extended an offer to Bersih to meet and discuss its demands, on the condition that the rally be called off. He claimed that during a previous meeting with Bersih in 2010, it had agreed that its demands were met.{{cite news |title=EC offers to meet Bersih if rally called off |url=http://www.themalaysianinsider.com/malaysia/article/ec-offers-to-meet-bersih-if-rally-called-off/ |work=[[The Malaysian Insider]] |date=20 June 2011 |accessdate=20 June 2011}} Bersih rejected the EC's offer.{{cite news |title=Bersih 2.0 to EC: Enough talk, now we walk |url=http://www.malaysiakini.com/news/167494 |work=[[Malaysiakini]] |date=20 June 2011 |author=Hafiz Yatim |accessdate=20 June 2011}} Speaking to reporters while observing the [[Thai general election, 2011|Thai general election]] in July, Abdul Aziz said the EC was considering allowing international observers to monitor the [[next Malaysian general election]].{{cite news |title=EC Mulls Inviting International Observers |url=http://www.bernama.com.my/bernama/v5/newsgeneral.php?id=598215 |publisher=[[Bernama]] |author=Jamaluddin Muhammad |date=1 July 2011 |accessdate=1 July 2011}} ===Government reaction=== Prime minister [[Najib Razak]] warned that Bersih would be responsible if chaos ensued from the rally.{{cite news |title=PM: July 9 rally organisers would be held responsible if chaos erupts |url=http://thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=/2011/6/26/nation/20110626132648&sec=nation |work=[[The Star (Malaysia)|The Star]] |date=26 June 2011 |author=Mazwin Nik Anis |accessdate=26 June 2011}} Home Minister [[Hishamuddin Hussein]] warned against the rally, fearing the chaos that might ensue. He affirmed on 7 June that the rally was "illegal," and urged the organisers to call it off.{{cite news |title=‘Ban on illegal demo is for safety’ |url=http://thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=/2011/6/7/nation/8849506&sec=nation |work=[[The Star (Malaysia)|''The Star'']] |date=7 June 2011 |accessdate=13 June 2011}} He promised to clamp down on demonstrators if they threatened national security.{{cite news |title=Bersih should clean up its act, says Home Minister |url=http://thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=/2011/5/23/nation/8737547&sec=nation |work=[[The Star (Malaysia)|''The Star'']] |date=23 May 2011 |accessdate=13 June 2011}}{{cite news |title=July 9 rally: No easy walk for Bersih, Perkasa |url=http://www.freemalaysiatoday.com/2011/06/15/july-9-rally-no-easy-walk-for-bersih-perkasa/ |work=Free Malaysia Today |date=15 July 2011 |last=Lee |first=Patrick |accessdate=15 July 2011}}{{cite news |title=Thumbing nose at Hisham, Khairy says march goes on |url=http://www.themalaysianinsider.com/malaysia/article/thumbing-nose-at-hisham-khairy-says-march-goes-on/ |work=[[The Malaysian Insider]] |date=17 June 2011 |last=Teoh |first=Shannon |accessdate=21 June 2011}} On 22 June, he confirmed that none of the three rallies would receive police permits to hold gatherings on 9 July.{{cite news |title=Hishammuddin: No permits for Bersih, Umno Youth and Perkasa |url=http://thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=/2011/6/22/nation/20110622125323&sec=nation |work=[[The Star (Malaysia)|The Star]] |date=22 June 2011 |author=Mazwin Nik Anis |accessdate=22 June 2011}} The government also outlawed the wearing and distribution of Bersih's yellow shirts and declared Bersih an illegal organisation under Section 5 of the Societies Act 1966.{{cite news |title=Bersih T-shirts illegal, declares Hisham |url=http://www.themalaysianinsider.com/malaysia/article/bersih-t-shirts-illegal-declares-hisham/ |work=[[The Malaysian Insider]] |date=29 June 2011 |last=Teoh |first=Shannon |accessdate=29 June 2011}}{{cite news |title=Bersih declared unlawful organisation |url=http://www.freemalaysiatoday.com/2011/07/02/bersih-declared-unlawful-organisation/ |work=Free Malaysia Today |date=2 July 2011 |author=Bernama |authorlink=Bernama |accessdate=3 July 2011}} Bersih countered that as a coalition of groups it need not be registered.{{cite news |title=Bersih 2.0: Coalitions need not be registered |url=http://www.malaysiakini.com/news/168839 |work=[[Malaysiakini]] |date=4 July 2011 |last=Sipalan |first=Joseph |accessdate=4 July 2011}} Najib initially offered Bersih the opportunity of holding the rally in a stadium instead of the streets.{{cite news |title=Pakatan willing to accept Najib’s stadium offer |url=http://my.news.yahoo.com/pakatan-willing-to-accept-najib-s-stadium-offer-043850816.html |work=[[The Malaysian Insider]] |date=5 July 2011 |last=Chooi |first=Clara |accessdate=9 July 2011}} The government later rejected Bersih's request to hold the rally at [[Merdeka Stadium]], and asked them to use a stadium in [[Selangor]] instead.{{cite news |title=Malaysia to Block Roads in Bid to Stop Protesters Demanding Fair Elections |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-07-08/malaysia-to-block-roads-in-bid-to-stop-protesters-demanding-fair-elections.html |publisher=Bloomberg |date=8 July 2011 |author1=Manirajan Ramasamy |last2=Gan |first=Yen Kuan |accessdate=8 July 2011}} However, the [[Sharafuddin of Selangor|Sultan of Selangor]] had previously condemned demonstrations.{{cite news |title=Despite obstacles, Bersih remains unwavering |url=http://www.malaysiakini.com/news/169357 |work=[[Malaysiakini]] |date=8 July 2011 |accessdate=8 July 2011}} ===Opposition reaction=== PAS deputy president [[Mohamad Sabu]] gave the rally his party's full backing.{{cite news |title=Bersih 2.0 diteruskan walau Perkasa halang |url=http://bm.harakahdaily.net/index.php/headline/3766-bersih-20-diteruskan-walau-perkasa-halang |work=Harakah Daily |date=13 June 2011 |author=Nazri Abdullah |accessdate=13 June 2011 }} Calling the event the "Walk for Democracy," he asked for 300,000 PAS members to attend the gathering. PAS president [[Abdul Hadi Awang]] ordered all of its members (numbering one million) to join the rally.{{cite news |title=PAS on million-man march for Bersih |url=http://www.themalaysianinsider.com/malaysia/article/pas-on-million-man-march-for-bersih/ |work=[[The Malaysian Insider]] |date=23 June 2011 |last=Yow |first=Hong Chieh |accessdate=23 June 2011}} The Leader of the Opposition, [[Anwar Ibrahim]], will also take part in the rally.{{cite news |title=Anwar ups the ante on Bersih 2.0 |url=http://www.malaysiakini.com/news/166694 |work=[[Malaysiakini]] |date=12 June 2011 |last=Netto |first=Terence |accessdate=13 June 2011}} The DAP also pledged support for the rally. On 19 June, Anwar reportedly told members of his [[Parti Keadilan Rakyat]] (PKR) that he would ask Ambiga to cancel the rally if the government met Bersih's demands.{{cite news |title=Anwar clarifies Bersih rally remark |url=http://www.freemalaysiatoday.com/2011/06/20/anwar-clarifies-bersih-rally-remark/ |work=Free Malaysia Today |date=20 June 2011 |author=Tarani Palani |accessdate=20 June 2011}} His statement was rebuffed by Ambiga the following day.{{cite news |title=Bersih rally go-ahead not up to Anwar, says Ambiga |url=http://www.themalaysianinsider.com/malaysia/article/bersih-rally-go-ahead-not-up-to-anwar-says-ambiga/ |work=[[The Malaysian Insider]] |date=20 June 2011 |last=Yow |first=Hong Chieh |accessdate=20 June 2011}} Anwar later claimed he was misquoted. This incident was criticised by ruling coalition parties, who have argued that the rally is in fact an opposition tool to gain support.{{cite news |title=Gerakan in a dilemma over Bersih rally |url=http://www.freemalaysiakini.com/modules.php?name=News&file=article&sid=14457&mode=thread&order=0&thold=0 |work=Malaysiakini |date=20 June 2011 |accessdate=20 June 2011}}{{cite news |title=Bersih rally tainted, claims Khairy |url=http://www.themalaysianinsider.com/malaysia/article/bersih-rally-tainted-claims-khairy/ |work=[[The Malaysian Insider]] |date=20 June 2011 |author=Asrul Hadi Abdullah Sani |accessdate=20 June 2011}} ===Non-governmental organisations=== The Bersih rally was backed by the [[Human Rights Commission of Malaysia]] (Suhakam),{{cite news |title=Suhakam: Allow peaceful assembly |url=http://www.dailyexpress.com.my/news.cfm?NewsID=78367 |work=Daily Express |location=UK |date=28 June 2011 |accessdate=1 July 2011}} Transparency International Malaysia (TI-M),{{cite news |title=Boost for Bersih from TI-M |url=http://www.freemalaysiatoday.com/2011/06/22/boost-for-bersih-from-ti-m/ |work=Free Malaysia Today |date=22 June 2011 |accessdate=1 July 2011}} and the Malaysian Consultative Council of Buddhism, Christianity, Hinduism, Sikhism and Taoism (MCCBCHST).{{cite news |title=Religious council throws its weight behind all three rallies |url=http://www.freemalaysiatoday.com/2011/07/01/religious-council-throws-its-weight-behind-all-three-rallies/ |work=Free Malaysia Today |date=1 July 2011 |author=Tarani Palani |accessdate=1 July 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110703100618/http://www.freemalaysiatoday.com/2011/07/01/religious-council-throws-its-weight-behind-all-three-rallies/ |archivedate=3 July 2011 |df=dmy-all }} The MCCBCHST also backed Perkasa and UMNO Youth's right to hold their rallies. [[Amnesty International]] called on the government to end the "mass repression" of Bersih activists.{{cite web |title=Malaysia: End mass repression of pro-reform activists |url=https://www.amnesty.org/en/news-and-updates/malaysia-end-mass-repression-pro-reform-activists-2011-06-30 |publisher=[[Amnesty International]] |date=30 June 2011 |accessdate=30 June 2011}}{{cite news |title=Int'l NGO calls for end to repression in KL |url=http://www.thejakartapost.com/news/2011/07/01/intl-ngo-calls-end-repression-kl.html |work=The Jakarta Post |date=1 July 2011 |author=Damar Harsanto |accessdate=1 July 2011}} [[Human Rights Watch]] urged the government to release all detained activists, return confiscated material, and permit the rally to proceed.{{cite news |title=Malaysia: End Crackdown on Peaceful Campaigners |url=http://www.trust.org/alertnet/news/malaysia-end-crackdown-on-peaceful-campaigners |author=Human Rights Watch |authorlink=Human Rights Watch |work=AlertNet |date=29 June 2011 |accessdate=29 June 2011}} Deputy Asia director Phil Robertson said "Governments that elected Malaysia to a second term on the [[UN Human Rights Council]] might feel duped." The Asia-Europe Peoples' Forum (AEPF), consisting of 120 international NGOs, condemned the Malaysian government for the crackdown on activists.{{cite news |title=NGOs in Asia and Europe condemn Najib |url=http://www.freemalaysiatoday.com/2011/07/09/ngos-in-asia-and-europe-condemn-najib/ |work=Free Malaysia Today |date=9 July 2011 |author=Syed Jaymal Zahiid |accessdate=9 July 2011}} ===International response=== On 5 July, the [[Office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights]] voiced concern about the restriction of freedom of expression in Malaysia and urged the government to release detained Bersih activists.{{cite web |title=Malaysia: UN rights office concerned at reported crackdown ahead of planned protests |url=https://www.un.org/apps/news/story.asp?NewsID=38935&Cr=expression&Cr1 |publisher=UN |date=5 July 2011 |accessdate=8 July 2011}} ===Threats of violence=== On 23 June, Ambiga received a death threat via text message.{{cite news |title=Ambiga receives SMS death threat |url=http://www.themalaysianinsider.com/malaysia/article/ambiga-receives-sms-death-threat/ |work=[[The Malaysian Insider]] |date=23 June 2011 |author=Shazwan Mustafa Kamal |accessdate=22 June 2011}} She remained defiant, saying "nothing has changed" and the rally will go on.{{cite news |title=Despite death threat, Ambiga says Bersih rally still on |url=http://www.themalaysianinsider.com/malaysia/article/despite-death-threat-ambiga-says-bersih-rally-still-on/ |work=[[The Malaysian Insider]] |date=23 June 2011 |author=Shazwan Mustafa Kamal |accessdate=23 June 2011}} The grandmaster of the Malaysian [[Silat|Silat Lincah]] Organisation (PSSLM) reportedly threatened to "wage war" against Bersih activists.{{cite news |title=Silat guru to hold 'war' talks tomorrow |url=http://www.freemalaysiatoday.com/2011/07/01/silat-guru-to-hold-war-talks-tomorrow/ |work=Free Malaysia Today |date=1 July 2011 |author=Syed Jaymal Zahiid |accessdate=1 July 2011}} Najib subsequently endorsed silat groups, including PSSLM.{{cite news |title=Malaysia braces for pro-democracy street protests in Kuala Lumpur |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2011/jul/08/malaysia-democracy-street-protests |work=The Guardian |location=UK |date=8 July 2011 |last=Hodal |first=Kate |accessdate=8 July 2011}} ===Yang di-Pertuan Agong's intervention=== Malaysia's head of state, the [[Yang di-Pertuan Agong]], [[Tuanku Mizan Zainal Abidin]], issued a statement on 3 July urging moderation by all parties. He said "street demonstrations bring more bad than good although the original intention is good," and called for Bersih to resolve its differences with the government peacefully. He also expressed confidence in Prime Minister [[Najib Razak]]'s administration.{{cite news |title=King issues statement on Bersih 2.0 rally |url=http://thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=/2011/7/3/nation/20110703233907&sec=nation |work=[[The Star (Malaysia)|The Star]] |date=3 July 2011 |author=Bernama |authorlink=Bernama |accessdate=3 July 2011}} Following an audience with the King, Ambiga announced that Bersih accepted the government's offer to hold the rally in a stadium instead of the streets.{{cite news |title=Bersih’s Ambiga: No street march, rally will be held in stadium |url=http://www.thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=/2011/7/5/nation/20110705160353&sec=nation |work=[[The Star (Malaysia)|The Star]] |date=5 July 2011 |last=Lee |first=Yen Mun |accessdate=5 July 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110708051317/http://www.thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=%2F2011%2F7%2F5%2Fnation%2F20110705160353&sec=nation |archivedate=8 July 2011 |df=dmy-all }}{{cite news |title=Ambiga: Bersih to rally in stadium, not on streets |url=http://www.themalaysianinsider.com/malaysia/article/ambiga-bersih-to-rally-in-stadium-not-on-streets/ |work=[[The Malaysian Insider]] |date=5 July 2011 |author=Syed Mu’az Syed Putra |accessdate=5 July 2011}} Despite Bersih's meeting with the King, the government maintained its stance that Bersih is illegal.{{cite news |title=Meeting king doesn’t make rally legal |url=http://www.freemalaysiatoday.com/2011/07/06/bersih-still-illegal-says-hisham/ |work=Free Malaysia Today |date=6 July 2011 |author=Tashny Sukumaran |accessdate=8 July 2011}} ===Police reports and reaction=== At least 2,136 police reports, from business operators, travel agencies, and UMNO Youth, were filed against Bersih since the rally's announcement.{{cite news |title=Deputy IGP: No permit to be issued for Bersih rally |url=http://www.thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=/2011/6/15/nation/20110615135831&sec=nation |work=[[The Star (Malaysia)|The Star]] |date=15 June 2011 |last1=Carvalho |first1=Martin |author2=Rahimy Rahim |last3=Camoens |first3=Austin |accessdate=15 June 2011}}{{cite news |title=Eight police reports against Bersih 2.0 rally |url=http://www.freemalaysiatoday.com/2011/06/09/eight-police-reports-against-bersih-2-0-rally/ |work=Free Malaysia Today |date=9 June 2011 |author=K. Pragalath |accessdate=13 June 2011}} On 15 June, the [[Royal Malaysia Police|police]] announced that permits would not be issued for any rally, saying that the rallies would "disturb the peace" and "cause traffic chaos." Bersih remained defiant despite not receiving the permit, and promised to co-operate with police during the gathering.{{cite news |title=Bersih insists on working with police for rally |url=http://www.themalaysianinsider.com/malaysia/article/bersih-insists-on-working-with-police-for-rally/ |work=[[The Malaysian Insider]] |date=15 June 2011 |last=Chi |first=Melissa |accessdate=15 June 2011}} Police also investigated allegations that Ambiga received funds from foreign NGOs "to cause chaos in Malaysia."{{cite news |title=Police to investigate Ambiga’s foreign funds |url=http://www.freemalaysiatoday.com/2011/07/04/police-to-investigate-ambigas-foreign-funds/ |work=Free Malaysia Today |date=4 July 2011 |author=Bernama |authorlink=Bernama |accessdate=4 July 2011}} Police recorded statements from Ambiga, Ibrahim, and opposition politicians ahead of the rally.{{cite news |title=Cops question Ibrahim, Ambiga and Samad about July 9 rallies |url=http://thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=/2011/6/28/nation/8987090&sec=nation |work=[[The Star (Malaysia)|The Star]] |date=28 June 2011 |accessdate=28 June 2011}}{{cite news |title=Cops quiz MPs in Parliament over Bersih |url=http://www.themalaysianinsider.com/malaysia/article/cops-quiz-mps-in-parliament-over-bersih/ |work=[[The Malaysian Insider]] |date=28 June 2011 |last=Chooi |first=Clara |accessdate=28 June 2011}} On 1 July, the police ceased discussions with Bersih, Perkasa and UMNO Youth and promised to prevent any street rallies from taking place.{{cite news |title=Deputy IGP: No more discussions over rallies |url=http://www.freemalaysiatoday.com/2011/07/01/deputy-igp-no-more-discussions-over-rallies/ |work=Free Malaysia Today |date=1 July 2011 |last=Teoh |first=El Sen |accessdate=1 July 2011}}{{cite news |title=Police to make sure July 9 rallies do 'not take place' |url=http://www.themalaysianinsider.com/malaysia/article/police-to-make-sure-july-9-rallies-do-not-take-place/ |work=[[The Malaysian Insider]] |date=1 July 2011 |author=Shazwan Mustafa Kamal |accessdate=1 July 2011}} ====Pre-rally arrests and raids==== [[File:Bersih 2 road block.JPG|thumb|The police enforced road blocks throughout the city to discourage turnout.]] More than 150 people were arrested before 9 July for Bersih-related activities, including distributing leaflets.{{cite news |title=Malaysia detains about 60 activists ahead of rally |url=https://www.google.com/hostednews/ap/article/ALeqM5g0tBeEbiYyX0RE7AZE6ItSdD4goQ?docId=0af052a1eba94885850ba537d546b9a4 |agency=Associated Press |authorlink=Associated Press |date=26 June 2011 |accessdate=26 June 2011}} Most were released after several hours of questioning. 30 members of [[Parti Sosialis Malaysia]] (PSM) were arrested in [[Penang]] on 26 June on suspicion of spreading communism and conspiring to overthrow the government.{{cite news |title=30 PSM members remanded till July 2 |url=http://www.freemalaysiatoday.com/2011/06/26/31-psm-members-still-in-police-custody/ |work=Free Malaysia Today |date=26 June 2011 |first=Humayun |last=Kabir |accessdate=30 June 2011}} Six members, including MP [[Michael Jeyakumar Devaraj]], remain held under the Emergency Ordinance 1969, which allows indefinite detention without trial.{{cite news |title=Malaysia holds MP and five activists under security law |url=https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5j-SBxNFK6HjiZ8l_2__54fOjsSEQ?docId=CNG.29ec5e12b6f0d10f7f43650910da4c43.531 |author=AFP |authorlink=Agence France Presse |date=2 July 2011 |accessdate=3 July 2011}} Police also raided and vandalised Bersih's office in [[Petaling Jaya]] on 30 June.{{cite news |title=Cops raid Bersih office |url=http://thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=/2011/6/30/nation/9003228&sec=nation |work=[[The Star (Malaysia)|The Star]] |date=30 June 2011 |accessdate=30 June 2011}} One day before the planned rally, police released a list of 91 individuals, including Ambiga, Khairy and Ibrahim, barred from entering Kuala Lumpur's central business district on 9 July.{{cite news |title=91 barred from city tomorrow |url=http://thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=/2011/7/8/nation/9057686&sec=nation |work=[[The Star (Malaysia)|The Star]] |date=8 July 2011 |accessdate=8 July 2011}} ====Lockdown==== Police began imposing roadblocks in the [[Klang Valley]] on Wednesday, 6 July, which led to massive traffic congestion and complaints from the public.{{cite news |title=Thousands left fuming over roadblocks |url=http://www.freemalaysiatoday.com/2011/07/06/thousands-of-motorists-left-fuming-over-police-roadblocks/ |work=Free Malaysia Today |date=6 July 2011 |last=Teoh |first=El Sen |accessdate=8 July 2011}} They described it as a "preventive" move to stop protesters from participating in the protest.{{cite news |title=Selangor CPO explains Wednesday morning roadblocks |url=http://thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=/2011/7/6/nation/20110706122426&sec=nation |work=[[The Star (Malaysia)|The Star]] |date=6 July 2011 |accessdate=8 July 2011}} On 8 July, police sealed off [[Merdeka Square, Kuala Lumpur|Merdeka Square]] and rolled in water cannon and riot police trucks.{{cite news |title=Police deployed at Dataran Merdeka, area sealed off |url=http://www.malaysiakini.com/news/169355 |work=[[Malaysiakini]] |date=8 July 2011 |last=Aw |first=Nigel |accessdate=8 July 2011}} At midnight on 9 July, major roads in the city was shut and public transportation suspended.{{cite news |title=Malaysia rally: Kuala Lumpur 'to be locked down' |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-pacific-14076424 |work=BBC News |date=8 July 2011 |accessdate=9 July 2011}} ==Protests== [[Kuala Lumpur]] was described as a "ghost town" on the morning of 9 July.
