Many offices and shops were closed as police maintained heavy presences in key areas.{{cite news |title=KL holds its breath as Bersih rally looms |url=http://www.themalaysianinsider.com/malaysia/article/kl-holds-its-breath-as-bersih-rally-looms/ |work=[[The Malaysian Insider]] |date=9 July 2011 |accessdate=9 July 2011}} Crowds began pouring in by noon, where they were met by police who took "extraordinary" security measures, known as "Operation Erase Bersih."{{cite news |title=Malaysian police crack down on protesters |url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/asia-pacific/2011/07/20117973119168783.html |publisher=Al Jazeera English |date=9 July 2011 |accessdate=9 July 2011}} Many were arrested and transported to the police training center (Pulapol).{{cite news |title=236 held as KL lock-down goes into full swing |url=http://www.freemalaysiatoday.com/2011/07/09/230-held-as-kl-lock-down-goes-into-full-swing/ |work=Free Malaysia Today |date=9 July 2011 |accessdate=9 July 2011}}{{cite news |title=Malaysia arrests 236 ahead of banned rally |url=https://www.google.com/hostednews/ap/article/ALeqM5haJTubxJ-R5cBUrT3m8K-tD8bLvw?docId=2dcbea0180604e2c82969fb733eb23b5 |agency=Associated Press |date=9 July 2011 |last=Yoong |first=Sean |accessdate=9 July 2011}} The protestors were arrested under Section 27 of the Police Act for planning to participate in illegal rallies, and face several years in prison if convicted. [[File:Bersih 2 protest.jpg|thumb|Protesters marching the streets of Kuala Lumpur peacefully before the police confronted them.]] [[File:Bersih FRU police.jpg|thumb|A member of the Federal Reserve Unit prepares to disperse the protesters with tear gas.]] [[File:Bersih 2 police charging.jpg|thumb|The police force charging at a crowd of regrouping protesters.]] Independent assessments put the rally numbers at between 10,000 and over 20,000, while Bersih claimed a turnout of 50,000.{{cite news|last=Roughneen|first=Simon|title=Malaysia nips an hibiscus uprising|url=http://www.atimes.com/atimes/Southeast_Asia/MG12Ae01.html|accessdate=12 July 2011|newspaper=Asia Times|date=12 July 2011}}{{cite news |title=Malaysia police detain hundreds at rally |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2011/jul/09/malaysia-opposition-protests-elections |work=The Guardian |location=UK |date=9 July 2011 |agency=Associated Press |authorlink=Associated Press |accessdate=9 July 2011}}{{cite news|last=Barta|first=Patrick|title=Malaysia Protest Lifts Opposition|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052702304584404576437604262329600|accessdate=11 July 2011|newspaper=Wall Street Journal|date=11 July 2011}} Major gathering points included Menara Maybank, Jalan Pudu, and [[Puduraya]] where riot police confronted protestors.{{cite news |title=Mayhem at Maybank HQ |url=http://www.themalaysianinsider.com/malaysia/article/tear-gas-fired-at-bersih-marchers-pas-vps-arrested/ |work=[[The Malaysian Insider]] |date=9 July 2011 |accessdate=9 July 2011}}{{cite news |title=Fortress KL: How did Bersih 2.0 slip past? |url=http://www.malaysiakini.com/news/169444 |work=[[Malaysiakini]] |date=10 July 2011 |author=Aidila Razak |accessdate=10 July 2011}} Thousands tried to reach Merdeka Stadium from various parts of the city, chanting ''"Hidup rakyat!"'' ("Long live the people!"). Police responded by firing numerous rounds of [[tear gas]] and chemical-laced water, causing the crowds to disperse into nearby buildings. Police continued to fire tear gas and chemical-laced water at the buildings. Many buildings were targeted by the police including a hospital which the police denied happened even though there are pictures of the water cannons spraying the hospital. At 14:00, Bersih and Pakatan Rakyat leaders began their march towards Merdeka Stadium. Shielded by hundreds of supporters, they pushed past three lines of police personnel awaiting them outside KL Sentral. Around 14:30, while walking with supporters in [[Brickfields]], Ambiga and fellow steering committee member Maria Chin Abdullah were arrested.{{cite news |title=Cops seize Ambiga, Pakatan leaders mid-march |url=http://www.themalaysianinsider.com/malaysia/article/bersih-leaders-begin-march/ |work=[[The Malaysian Insider]] |date=9 July 2011 |accessdate=9 July 2011}} Opposition politicians detained include [[Abdul Hadi Awang]], [[Mohamad Sabu]], [[Salahuddin Ayub]], [[Mahfuz Omar]], [[Dzulkefly Ahmad]], [[Azmin Ali]], [[Tian Chua]], [[Fuziah Salleh]], [[Sivarasa Rasiah]], and [[Ngeh Koo Ham]].{{cite news |title=Ambiga, Pakatan leaders arrested; Anwar hurt |url=http://www.freemalaysiatoday.com/2011/07/09/ambiga-pakatan-leaders-arrested/ |work=Free Malaysia Today |date=9 July 2011 |accessdate=9 July 2011}} [[Anwar Ibrahim]] said he sustained a bruise on his head and a cut leg when police fired live rounds.{{cite news |title=Thousands of Malaysians Rally for Changes to Elections |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/07/10/world/asia/10malaysia.html?_r=1 |work=The New York Times |date=9 July 2011 |last=Gooch |first=Liz |accessdate=10 July 2011}} PAS MP [[Khalid Samad]] was said to have suffered a serious head injury and was admitted to hospital. UMNO Youth's rally in Bukit Bintang however, was allowed to on peacefully without intervention from the police. Around 1,000 protestors eventually reached Merdeka Stadium, including national laureate [[A. Samad Said]] and PAS's [[Husam Musa]].{{cite news |title=Crowd dispersing from Stadium Merdeka, gathering in KLCC |url=http://www.themalaysianinsider.com/malaysia/article/headless-bersih-rally-still-growing-at-stadium/ |work=[[The Malaysian Insider]] |date=9 July 2011 |accessdate=9 July 2011}} At around 16:00, the crowd voluntarily began dispersing. However, police continued to fire tear gas and chemical-laced water at any individual and moved in to arrest them. Another group of protestors tried to reach the [[Istana Negara, Jalan Istana|National Palace]], while a third group gathered at [[KLCC Park|Kuala Lumpur City Centre (KLCC) Park]] beneath the [[Petronas Twin Towers]].{{cite news |title=Malaysian Police Fire Tear Gas at Kuala Lumpur Protesters |url=http://www.businessweek.com/news/2011-07-09/malaysian-police-fire-tear-gas-at-kuala-lumpur-protesters.html |publisher=Bloomberg |date=9 July 2011 |author1=Manirajan Ramasamy |last2=Gan |first2=Gan |accessdate=9 July 2011}} Thousands eventually gathered at KLCC but were dispersed by police using tear gas and chemically-laced water.{{cite news |title=Clashes, chaos in KL as police fire on crowds |url=http://www.freemalaysiatoday.com/2011/07/09/thousands-march-numbers-swell-by-the-minute/ |work=Free Malaysia Today |date=9 July 2011 |accessdate=9 July 2011}} By 18:40 in the evening, police had confirmed 1,667 arrests, including 167 females and minors.{{cite news |url=http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/g/a/2011/07/08/bloomberg1376-LO2LKK0UQVI901-093V3E0G483HR0O083LMTPRJNH.DTL |title=Malaysian Police Fire Tear Gas, Arrest 1,667 in Street Protests |date=9 July 2011 |work=San Francisco Chronicle |accessdate=9 July 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110713135418/http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=%2Fg%2Fa%2F2011%2F07%2F08%2Fbloomberg1376-LO2LKK0UQVI901-093V3E0G483HR0O083LMTPRJNH.DTL |archivedate=13 July 2011 |df=dmy-all }} Most of the arrested protestors, including Ambiga, were freed by the end of the day.{{cite news |title=Ambiga and Hadi freed, claim victory for democracy |url=http://www.malaysiakini.com/news/169419 |work=[[Malaysiakini]] |date=9 July 2011 |last1=Aw |first1=Nigel |last2=Sipalan |first2=Joseph |accessdate=10 July 2011}} One death was reported. Protestor Baharuddin Ahmad accidentally inhaled tear gas fired by police. He was later arrested, but when he started to black out police didn't do anything and just stood there and watched. He was restrained by handcuffs which made the matters worse and he wasn't released because police lost the keys. After 15 minutes, an ambulance was called but never arrived. Finally, a volunteer took Baharuddin to a nearby hospital but it was already too late.{{cite news |title=Protest claims one life |url=http://www.freemalaysiatoday.com/2011/07/09/protest-claims-one-life/ |work=Free Malaysia Today |date=9 July 2011 |author=Tarani Palani |accessdate=9 July 2011}} Police said he died of heart complications.{{cite news |title=Bersih 2.0 protester died of heart problem |url=http://www.nst.com.my/nst/articles/Bersih2_0protesterdiedofheartproblem/Article/ |work=[[New Straits Times]] |date=10 July 2011 |accessdate=10 July 2011}}http://www.malaysiakini.com/news/169469http://www.malaysiakini.com/news/169480{{Cite web |url=http://en.harakahdaily.net/index.php/headline/3109-questions-surround-baharudins-death-despite-police-denial.html |title=Archived copy |access-date=11 July 2011 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110713220556/http://en.harakahdaily.net/index.php/headline/3109-questions-surround-baharudins-death-despite-police-denial.html |archive-date=13 July 2011 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }} ===International protests=== Bersih rallies also commenced in Melbourne, Sydney, Perth, Adelaide, Brisbane and Canberra, Australia, attracting around 750 people, 300 people, 200 people, 150 people, 50 people and 30 people respectively. Rallies were also reported in Auckland, Wellington and Christchurch, New Zealand,{{cite news|url=http://www.malaysiakini.com/news/169398|title=Global Bersih rallies kick off in Melbourne|date=9 July 2011|work=[[Malaysiakini]]|accessdate=9 July 2011}}http://www.greenleft.org.au/node/48113 as well as in London, England.{{cite news|url=http://thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=/2011/7/10/nation/9074540&sec=nation|title=Pro-Bersih rallies in Melbourne, London|date=10 July 2011|work=[[The Star (Malaysia)]]|accessdate=10 July 2011}} A gathering of about 120 people was reported at the [[Speakers' Corner, Singapore|Speaker's Corner]] at [[Hong Lim Park]], Singapore.http://www.straitstimes.com/BreakingNews/Singapore/Story/STIStory_689148.html Further rallies were reported in central Hong Kong,http://www.malaysiakini.com/news/169410 Taiwan,http://www.taipeitimes.com/News/taiwan/archives/2011/07/10/2003507872 Japan, South Korea, Switzerland, Sweden, France, England, Scotland, Ireland, Canada and the United States.{{cite web|last=Teoh, Sukumaran|first=El Sen, Tashny|title=Bersih Walk Around the World|url=http://www.freemalaysiatoday.com/2011/07/11/bersih-walks-around-the-world/|publisher=Free Malaysia Today|accessdate=11 July 2011}} ==Aftermath== National laureate [[A. Samad Said]] called the rally a "great success", lauding the multiracial unity among the protestors.{{cite news |title=Bersih says 50,000 protested, declares rally ‘great success’ |url=http://www.themalaysianinsider.com/malaysia/article/bersih-says-50000-protested-declares-rally-great-success/ |work=[[The Malaysian Insider]] |date=9 July 2011 |accessdate=9 July 2011}} Ambiga, speaking after being released, congratulated those who attended the rally, saying "we were not intimidated." The Bersih leadership commended protestors for behaving peacefully and condemned the police for reacting harshly to the demonstration.{{cite news |title=This is just the beginning, says polls coalition |url=http://www.malaysiakini.com/news/169403 |work=[[Malaysiakini]] |date=9 July 2011 |accessdate=9 July 2011}} They said the gathering was "not the end, it is but one more step in the long walk for clean and fair elections in Malaysia." Leader of the Opposition [[Anwar Ibrahim]] said the rally was a "success" despite "police brutality."{{cite news |title=Anwar: I suffered a bruise and a cut leg |url=http://www.malaysiakini.com/news/169433 |work=[[Malaysiakini]] |date=9 July 2011 |author=AFP |authorlink=Agence France Presse |accessdate=10 July 2011}} DAP secretary-general [[Lim Guan Eng]] said the "police abuse" was "a big blow to the image of Malaysia."{{cite news |title=Guan Eng: Police abuse at rally bad image for M'sia |url=http://www.malaysiakini.com/news/169454 |work=[[Malaysiakini]] |date=10 July 2011 |last=Loone |first=Susan |accessdate=10 July 2011}} Prime Minister [[Najib Razak]] downplayed the rally, insisting it only represented a minority of the population.{{cite news |title=Najib: Let illegal rally be a lesson to the people |url=http://thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=/2011/7/10/nation/9074694&sec=nation |work=[[The Star (Malaysia)|The Star]] |date=10 July 2011 |accessdate=10 July 2011}} He also said the anti-government sentiment among the protestors confirmed the government's fears that Bersih's agenda had been hijacked by the opposition. Home Minister [[Hishamuddin Hussein]] praised the police for keeping the rally under control and said the rally revealed itself to be an opposition plot.{{cite news |title=Bersih rally lost direction, says Hishammuddin |url=http://www.themalaysianinsider.com/malaysia/article/bersih-rally-lost-direction-says-hishammuddin/ |work=[[The Malaysian Insider]] |date=9 July 2011 |last=Teoh |first=Shannon |accessdate=9 July 2011}} The United States expressed concern over the crackdown. [[United States Department of State|State Department]] spokesman Mark Toner said "We stand for... the right for people to freely express their democratic aspirations and express their views freely."{{cite news |title=US concern at Malaysia crackdown on protests |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-pacific-14149828 |work=BBC News |date=14 July 2011 |accessdate=14 July 2011}} Amnesty International released a statement saying: "This brutal crackdown on peaceful protesters is undermining Malaysia’s claim to be a moderate democracy. Mr. Najib’s government has chosen the path of repression, not reform." Lawyers for Liberty released a statement saying that the police deliberately shot gas canisters against the protestors.http://www.malaysiakini.com/news/169623 ===Reform proposals=== On 15 August 2011, Najib announced that a parliamentary select committee will be formed to examine the electoral system. He said the committee will consist of members of parliament from both the government and opposition coalition who will discuss electoral reform issues "so that a mutual agreement can be reached."{{cite news |title=In nod to Bersih, PM announces vote system relook |url=http://www.themalaysianinsider.com/malaysia/article/pm-announces-bi-partisan-panel-to-study-vote-system/ |work=[[The Malaysian Insider]] |date=15 August 2011 |author=Shazwan Mustafa Kamal |accessdate=15 August 2011}} In his [[Malaysia Day]] 2011 address in September, Najib announced the government's intentions to repeal the [[Internal Security Act (Malaysia)|Internal Security Act]], [[Emergency Ordinance]], remove the annual renewal of press and publication permits, and review Section 27 of the [[Police (Malaysia) Act 1967|Police Act]].{{cite web |title=PM announces repeal of ISA, three Emergency proclamations |url=http://thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=/2011/9/15/nation/20110915205714&sec=nation |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120101122631/http://thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=%2F2011%2F9%2F15%2Fnation%2F20110915205714&sec=nation |dead-url=yes |archive-date=1 January 2012 |work=[[The Star (Malaysia)|The Star]] |date=15 September 2011 |accessdate=15 September 2011 |df=dmy-all }} In November 2011, the government tabled the [[Peaceful Assembly Act]] to replace Section 27 of the Police Act.{{cite news |title=Gathering in peace |url=http://www.nst.com.my/opinion/editorial/gathering-in-peace-1.9695 |work=[[New Straits Times]] |date=23 November 2011 |accessdate=23 November 2011 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111123165426/http://www.nst.com.my/opinion/editorial/gathering-in-peace-1.9695 |archive-date=23 November 2011 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }} ==Coverage and analysis== ===Pre-rally=== The lead-up to the rally has received polarising coverage in Malaysia's print and internet news media. Malaysia's print media are subject to the [[Printing Presses and Publications Act]], which stipulates they can only publish with a license granted by the [[Ministry of Home Affairs (Malaysia)|Ministry of Home Affairs]].{{cite journal|title=Malaysia |url=http://pcmlp.socleg.ox.ac.uk/archive/transition/issue07/malaysia.htm |work=Communications Law in Transition Newsletter |publisher=Oxford University, [[Yeshiva University]] |volume=1 |number=7 |date=4 September 2000 |accessdate=21 June 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110724150414/http://pcmlp.socleg.ox.ac.uk/archive/transition/issue07/malaysia.htm |archivedate=24 July 2011 |df=dmy }} A news website has alleged that the [[Malaysian Communications and Multimedia Commission]] instructed radio and television stations to omit coverage of police violence and focus on the damage done by rally participants.{{cite news |title=Govt to media: Black out police violence during rally |url=http://en.harakah.net.my/index.php/berita-utama/3046-govt-to-media-black-out-police-violence-during-rally.html |work=Harakah Daily |date=1 July 2011 |accessdate=3 July 2011}} State news agency [[Bernama]] quoted several political analysts saying that the rally will tarnish Malaysia's image abroad and is a distraction from [[Anwar Ibrahim]]'s ongoing [[Anwar Ibrahim sodomy trials|sodomy trials]]. It claimed the 1998 demonstrations against Anwar's arrest and the 2007 Bersih rally caused "inconvenience to the public and damage to public property, attracting bad publicity from the international media." One analyst said elections are "already fair as fair can be."{{cite news |title=Illegal assembly will tarnish Malaysia’s good image: Analysts |url=http://thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=/2011/6/23/nation/20110623171618&sec=nation |work=[[The Star (Malaysia)|The Star]] |date=23 June 2011 |author=Bernama |authorlink=Bernama |accessdate=24 June 2011}} Bernama also reported analysts saying that Ambiga has a history of provoking Muslims and working against interests of the Malay community.{{cite news |title=Malays should know who Ambiga is, say analysts |url=http://www.freemalaysiatoday.com/2011/06/26/malays-should-know-who-ambiga-is-say-analysts/ |work=Free Malaysia Today |date=26 June 2011 |author=Bernama |authorlink=Bernama |accessdate=26 June 2011 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110627032803/http://www.freemalaysiatoday.com/2011/06/26/malays-should-know-who-ambiga-is-say-analysts/ |archive-date=27 June 2011 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }} ====Print media==== ''[[Utusan Malaysia]]'', a newspaper owned by the [[United Malays National Organisation]] (UMNO), a governing party, criticised the rally as "dirty" on a 12 June editorial. In particular, it made reference to Anwar's sodomy trial and sex video allegations, calling him a hypocrite and urging Malaysians to protest against the opposition leader instead. It also warned against disunity among [[Malay people|Malays]], and claimed that the DAP, backed strongly by Chinese constituents, would benefit most from the rally.{{cite news |title=Utusan says Bersih dirty, calls for boycott |url=http://www.themalaysianinsider.com/malaysia/article/utusan-says-bersih-dirty-calls-for-boycott/ |work=[[The Malaysian Insider]] |date=12 June 2011 |last=Teoh |first=Shannon |accessdate=13 June 2011}} ''Utusan'' reported that 70 percent of the 1000 who attended the Bersih 2.0 pre-launch on 19 June were non-Malay.{{cite news |title=70 peratus bukan Melayu hadir |url=http://www.utusan.com.my/utusan/info.asp?y=2011&dt=0621&pub=Utusan_Malaysia&sec=Dalam_Negeri&pg=dn_06.htm |work=[[Utusan Malaysia]] |date=20 June 2011 |accessdate=20 June 2011}} The newspaper has also portrayed the rally as anti-Islam.{{cite news |title=Bukan budaya Islam |url=http://www.utusan.com.my/utusan/info.asp?y=2011&dt=0701&pub=Utusan_Malaysia&sec=Dalam_Negeri&pg=dn_09.htm |work=[[Utusan Malaysia]] |language=Malay |date=30 June 2011 |accessdate=30 June 2011}} They quoted pro-UMNO political analysts attacking Ambiga for "angering Muslims and Malays,"{{cite news |title=Utusan demonises Ambiga ahead of Bersih rally |url=http://www.themalaysianinsider.com/malaysia/article/utusan-demonises-ambiga-ahead-of-bersih-rally/ |work=[[The Malaysian Insider]] |date=26 June 2011 |author=Shazwan Mustafa Kamal |accessdate=27 June 2011}} as well as reported that foreign Christian organisations are funding the rally.{{cite news |title=Utusan says foreign Christian funds behind Bersih |url=http://www.themalaysianinsider.com/malaysia/article/utusan-says-foreign-christian-funds-behind-bersih/ |work=[[The Malaysian Insider]] |date=27 June 2011 |last=Teoh |first=Shannon |accessdate=27 June 2011}} Tay Tian Yan wrote in the ''[[Sin Chew Daily]]'', the highest circulated daily in Malaysia, that the rally is a repeat scenario of the 2007 protest, where the opposition cashed in on public discontent over rising prices and staged the rally to generate momentum ahead of the general election. He also noted that the counter-rally by UMNO Youth is a ploy by BN to mitigate the Bersih rally's momentum, as opposed to suppressing the rally outright, which he said would swing public opinion against BN.{{cite news |title=Massive mobilisation |url=http://www.mysinchew.com/node/59071 |work=[[Sin Chew Daily]] |date=20 June 2011 |last=Tay |first=Tuan Yan |accessdate=21 June 2011}} Lim Sue Goan noted the involvement of Pakatan Rakyat and UMNO in opposite rallies, and said the event has grown from becoming a mere march to demand free elections to a political showdown between the government and opposition.{{cite news |title=Political struggle |url=http://www.mysinchew.com/node/59584 |work=[[Sin Chew Daily]] |date=28 June 2011 |last=Lim |first=Sue Goan |accessdate=29 June 2011}} In a 22 June editorial, [[The Star (Malaysia)|''The Star'']], owned by the [[Malaysian Chinese Association]] (MCA), also a governing party, said opposition parties are colluding with the rally's organisers to discredit the authorities in an attempt to gain support ahead of the elections. It accused Bersih of "[creating] cynical distrust in the authorities to give [themselves] and their political ringleaders a psychological advantage."{{cite news |title=Bersih 2.0 rally is still politics all the same |url=http://thestar.com.my/columnists/story.asp?col=thestarsays&file=/2011/6/22/columnists/thestarsays/8949840&sec=The%20Star%20Says |work=[[The Star (Malaysia)|The Star]] |date=22 June 2011 |accessdate=27 June 2011}} Johan Jaaffar, chairman of Media Prima (owned by UMNO), the parent company of the ''[[New Straits Times]]'', wrote in the paper: "The government of the day is not perfect. So, too, the system... we don't solve problems on the streets. That's not us, nor our way."{{cite news |title=We don't solve problems on the streets |url=http://www.nst.com.my/nst/articles/19joja/Article/#ixzz1RZbx0HPC |work=[[New Straits Times]] |date=7 July 2011 |author=Johan Jaaffar |accessdate=9 July 2011}} M Faqih, writing in the PAS organ ''Harakah Daily'', compared the planned rally to the September 1998 protests in Kuala Lumpur against then-deputy prime minister [[Anwar Ibrahim]]'s sacking and detention on sodomy and corruption charges, which he described as peaceful unlike the [[Tunisian revolution|revolutions in Tunisia]] and [[2011 Egyptian revolution|Egypt]]. He called on the opposition to seize the initiative with public discontent over government policies and use the rally as a stepping stone to victory in next general election.{{cite news |title=9 Julai penentu akhir tarikh PRU 13 |url=http://bm.harakahdaily.net/index.php/articles/analysis-a-opinion/3879-9-julai-penentu-akhir-tarikh-pru-13- |work=Harakah Daily |author=M Faqih |accessdate=21 June 2011}} ====Internet news==== Josh Hong of ''[[Malaysiakini]]'' questioned the law requiring protest organisers to obtain permits, saying the freedom of speech and right to assembly are guaranteed by the Constitution. He also criticised the government's record of cracking down civil rights campaigners and political activists and the mainstream media's demonisation of the Bersih rally.{{cite news |title=Najib is losing the plot – again |url=http://www.malaysiakini.com/columns/169311 |work=[[Malaysiakini]] |date=8 July 2011 |last=Hong |first=Josh |accessdate=8 July 2011}} Fellow columnists Mariam Mokhtar and Dean Johns criticised the government's crackdown on Bersih.{{cite news |title=The follies of Umno and the EC |url=http://www.malaysiakini.com/columns/168837 |work=[[Malaysiakini]] |date=4 July 2011 |author=Mariam Mokhtar |accessdate=8 July 2011}}{{cite news |title='Let them eat dirt' |url=http://www.malaysiakini.com/columns/169047 |work=[[Malaysiakini]] |date=5 July 2011 |last=Johns |first=Dean |accessdate=8 July 2011}} News website ''[[The Malaysian Insider]]'' called the government's tough stand against the Bersih rally "double standards," deriding the government's non-action against Ibrahim Ali, who had earlier called for [[jihad]] against Christians. It also blamed the police for the chaos that occurred during the 2007 rally and dismissed the government's concern for national security and threat to tourism as self-caused.{{cite news |title=Putrajaya’s double standards – The Malaysian Insider |url=http://www.themalaysianinsider.com/sideviews/article/putrajayas-double-standards-the-malaysian-insider/ |work=[[The Malaysian Insider]] |date=13 June 2011 |accessdate=21 June 2011 }} The website reported analysts saying the rally will help PAS cement the growing support the party has gained among the Malay community.{{cite news |title=For PAS, Bersih rally catalyst to lead Malay vote |url=http://www.themalaysianinsider.com/malaysia/article/for-pas-bersih-rally-catalyst-to-lead-malay-vote/ |work=[[The Malaysian Insider]] |date=27 June 2011 |author=Shazwan Mustafa Kamal |accessdate=27 June 2011}} ''Free Malaysia Today'', another news website, argued in favour of the rally, saying that concerns that it will serve as a "spring offensive" to overthrow the government are exaggerated. It lamented what it perceived as Malaysia's flawed democracy, saying "[there] are two ways to punish political perverts who have raped democracy: vote them out or take to the streets." It also criticised the government for threatening to clamp down on protestors, saying that the ruling coalition is using public order as an excuse to preserve its stay in power.{{cite news |title=Don’t walk away from democracy |url=http://www.freemalaysiatoday.com/2011/06/21/dont-walk-away-from-democracy/ |work=Free Malaysia Today |date=21 June 2011 |accessdate=21 June 2011}} In another editorial the day before the rally, FMT was highly critical of the government, asking the people to "decide the course of history" and defy a "harsh and repressive" state.{{cite news |title=People, the choice is yours |url=http://www.freemalaysiatoday.com/2011/07/08/people-the-choice-is-yours/ |work=Free Malaysia Today |date=8 July 2011 |accessdate=8 July 2011}} ====International==== In an op-ed for ''[[The Wall Street Journal]]'', former US ambassador to Malaysia John R. Malott said Najib's UMNO is "running scared" of losing power and is waging a campaign of intimidation against Bersih. He called the protest "a brave step" towards the country's transition to full democracy.{{cite news |title=Running Scared in Malaysia |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052702303544604576431443001815406?mod=googlenews_wsj |work=The Wall Street Journal |date=8 July 2011 |last=Malott |first=John R. |accessdate=8 July 2011}} Professor Clive Kessler of the University of New South Wales in an interview with ABC Radio stated that the Agong's intervention was a rebuke to Umno and the government and an acknowledgement of Bersih’s legitimacy.{{Cite web |url=http://www.freemalaysiatoday.com/2011/07/06/a-royal-rebuke-for-umno-says-aussie-don/ |title=Archived copy |access-date=12 July 2011 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110710134614/http://www.freemalaysiatoday.com/2011/07/06/a-royal-rebuke-for-umno-says-aussie-don/ |archive-date=10 July 2011 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }} ===Reactions to the rally=== Newspapers owned by Barisan Nasional parties were highly critical of the rally, accusing Bersih of disturbing the peace.{{cite news |title=Print media attacks Bersih, praises cops |url=http://www.themalaysianinsider.com/malaysia/article/print-media-attacks-bersih-praises-cops/ |work=[[The Malaysian Insider]] |date=10 July 2011 |last=Teoh |first=Shannon |accessdate=10 July 2011}} ''[[Utusan Malaysia]]'' called the police operation to foil the illegal rally a success.{{cite news |title=Polis berjaya kekang Bersih |url=http://www.utusan.com.my/utusan/info.asp?y=2011&dt=0710&pub=Utusan_Malaysia&sec=Muka_Hadapan&pg=mh_01.htm |work=[[Utusan Malaysia]] |date=9 July 2011 |accessdate=10 July 2011 |language=Malay}} [[The Star (Malaysia)|''The Star'']] remarked in an editorial the following day: "If every complaint made one or the other party take to the streets, bringing a city to a standstill, people would not be getting much work done." It said Bersih achieved the publicity it sought, and that everyone should move on.{{cite news |title=The game is over, time for everybody to move on |url=http://thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=/2011/7/10/nation/9074695&sec=nation |work=[[The Star (Malaysia)|The Star]] |date=10 July 2011 |accessdate=10 July 2011}} The ''[[New Straits Times]]'' said there was "no winner in this madness" as many were hurt, and "Bersih's intentions were hijacked by the opposition coalition."{{cite news |title=No winner in this madness |url=http://www.nst.com.my/nst/articles/2bek/Article/#ixzz1Rfkmctle |work=[[New Straits Times]] |date=10 July 2011 |accessdate=10 July 2011}} NST's 10 July front page featured a photo of a protestor throwing an object with the headline "Peaceful?" ''[[The Malaysian Insider]]''{{'}}s Debra Chong said Najib's administration "took a massive punch to its gut," as accounts of police personnel using tear gas and water cannons against unarmed civilians were reported by international media. She said the rally showed the willingness of the middle class and civil society to stand up to the government.{{cite news |title=Today, Malaysians revisit Bersih 2007 |url=http://www.themalaysianinsider.com/malaysia/article/today-malaysians-revisit-bersih-2007/ |work=[[The Malaysian Insider]] |date=9 July 2011 |last=Chong |first=Debra |accessdate=9 July 2011}} TMI's Sheridan Mahavera said the rally was a display of racial unity.{{cite news |title=In Bersih, an elusive Malaysian unity appears |url=http://www.themalaysianinsider.com/malaysia/article/in-bersih-an-elusive-malaysian-unity-appears/ |work=[[The Malaysian Insider]] |date=10 July 2011 |author=Sheridan Mahavera |accessdate=10 July 2011}} Jeswan Kaur of ''Free Malaysia Today'' said Najib and the police were to blame for the chaotic scenes.{{cite news |title=Bersih rally revealed lots of truth |url=http://www.freemalaysiatoday.com/2011/07/10/bersih-rally-revealed-lots-of-truth/ |work=Free Malaysia Today |date=10 July 2011 |author=Jeswan Kaur |accessdate=10 July 2011}} Ibrahim Suffian, head of the Merdeka Center, an independent think tank, said the actions of Bersih and the government polarised Malaysians of opposite political opinions. "For Pakatan Rakyat supporters, it has just increased their scepticism of the [BN-ruled] government. For those who are pro-government, it has hardened their belief that the PR is out to cause trouble." One analyst accused Barisan Nasional of abusing public institutions to protect its power,{{cite news |title=BN slammed for ‘feudal politics’ |url=http://www.freemalaysiatoday.com/2011/07/10/bn-slammed-for-%E2%80%98feudal-politics%E2%80%99/ |work=Free Malaysia Today |date=10 July 2011 |author=Athi Shankar |accessdate=10 July 2011}} while another added that "the police lost more credibility than the protesters." International reaction was unanimously critical of the government. The Singapore [[The Straits Times|''Straits Times'']] added that Malaysian society has been polarised by the country’s divisive politics as clearly demonstrated when thousands braved a security lockdown of Kuala Lumpur.{{Cite web |url=http://www.themalaysianinsider.com/malaysia/article/singapore-daily-says-najib-umno-badly-bruised-by-bersih-crackdown/ |title=Archived copy |access-date=12 July 2011 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110713143524/http://www.themalaysianinsider.com/malaysia/article/singapore-daily-says-najib-umno-badly-bruised-by-bersih-crackdown/ |archive-date=13 July 2011 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }} In an editorial, the [[The Jakarta Post|''Jakarta Post'']] described Malaysia as a "rich but not free" country, with its leaders still "laboring under an old paradigm" and refusing to allow its people to exercise their rights to free speech by invoking racial tension.{{cite web|url=http://www.thejakartapost.com/news/2011/07/11/editorial-malaysia-rich-not-free.html|title=Malaysia: Rich, but not free|date=11 July 2011|accessdate=13 July 2011}} [[Al Jazeera English]]'s [[Teymoor Nabili]] said the government acted out of fear of an Egypt-style revolution.{{cite news |title=Malaysia's fear of Egypt |url=http://blogs.aljazeera.net/asia/2011/07/08/malaysias-fear-egypt |publisher=Al Jazeera English |date=9 July 2011 |last=Nabili |first=Teymoor |accessdate=9 July 2011}} [[Bloomberg L.P.|Bloomberg]] columnist William Pesek calls the rally a part of the "rising call for political change in Asia" that play a decisive role in foreign investment to Asian countries.{{cite news|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-07-12/investing-101-means-looking-out-the-windows-more-william-pesek.html|last=Pesek|first=William|title=Investing 101 Means Looking Out the Windows More|date=13 July 2011|accessdate=14 July 2011|work=Bloomberg}} The Asian Sentinel stated that although Najib Tun Razak appears to have won the battle by closing down Kuala Lumpur on Saturday and arresting 1,667 mostly peaceful marchers and would-be marchers, the consensus seems to be that Malaysia has suffered a blow to its international reputation as a moderate, democratic country.http://www.asiasentinel.com/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=3307&Itemid=251 ''[[The Guardian]]''{{'}}s Simon Tisdall slammed Malaysian Prime Minister Najib Razak's harsh treatment towards the peaceful rally participants, noting that the British Prime Minister [[David Cameron]] should tell Najib that "strong-arm tactics against protesters are unacceptable" and that "Malaysia's leaders should wake up and smell the coffee".[https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2011/jul/13/malaysia-najib-cameron-protesters Malaysia's Najib must abandon the Mubarak model] ===Censorship=== ''[[The Economist]]''{{'}}s coverage of the rally was partially censored by the government. Four lines in the article titled "Taken to the cleaners – an overzealous government response to an opposition rally" was inked out.{{cite news |title=Home Ministry censors Bersih article in The Economist |url=http://www.themalaysianinsider.com/malaysia/article/home-ministry-censors-bersih-article-in-the-economist/ |work=[[The Malaysian Insider]] |date=19 July 2011 |first=Clara |last=Chooi |accessdate=15 August 2011}} Najib later admitted that censoring parts of the article was a mistake which generated negative publicity.{{cite news |title=Najib: Censorship no longer ‘effective’, needs review |url=http://www.themalaysianinsider.com/malaysia/article/najib-censorship-no-longer-effective-needs-review/ |work=[[The Malaysian Insider]] |date=15 August 2011 |author=Shazwan Mustafa Kamal |accessdate=15 August 2011}} ==Criticism== ===Election Commission=== The [[Election Commission of Malaysia]] (EC) has dismissed Bersih's claims, saying that it has already met the organisation's demands. EC chairman Abdul Aziz Mohd Yusof, who met with Bersih officials in December 2010, slammed Bersih chairman Ambiga's knowledge of voter registration as "shallow."{{cite news |title=SPR jawab tuntutan 'Bersih' |url=http://www.utusan.com.my/utusan/info.asp?y=2011&dt=0614&pub=Utusan_Malaysia&sec=Rencana&pg=re_01.htm |work=[[Utusan Malaysia]] |author=Zulkifli Jalil |language=Malay |accessdate=13 June 2011}} Abdul Aziz also claimed that Bersih had a political agenda, saying that the opposition parties were propping up the organisation. He claimed the opposition were using the EC as a scapegoat for political gain.{{cite news |title=EC tells Bersih: Don’t make EC a scapegoat |url=http://thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=/2011/6/20/nation/20110620190723&sec=nation |work=[[The Star (Malaysia)|The Star]] |date=20 June 2011 |author=Bernama |authorlink=Bernama |accessdate=20 June 2011}} ====Response to demands==== * Responding to Bersih's demand that voter registration be automatic once a citizen reaches voting age, Abdul Aziz said such a proposal would contravene [[:s:Constitution of Malaysia#Article 119|Article 119 (4)]] of the Constitution, which he claims clearly states that registration as a voter can only be done through application by the voter him/herself. EC deputy chairman Wan Ahmad Wan Omar added that unregistered voters are "indifferent," and will not bother to vote anyway.{{cite news |title=EC shoots down Bersih’s demands ahead of rally |url=http://www.themalaysianinsider.com/malaysia/article/ec-shoots-down-bersihs-demands-ahead-of-rally/ |work=[[The Malaysian Insider]] |date=30 June 2011 |author=Shazwan Mustafa Kamal |accessdate=30 June 2011}} * Abdul Aziz also defended against allegations that the EC is lackadaisical in tackling [[Ghost voter|phantom voting]]. He said that the EC cannot strike names of dead voters off the electoral roll unless the family of a dead voter requests it and produces the dead voter's death certificate. He also blamed allegations of voting in multiple constituencies on voters who refuse to change the addresses on their identification cards when they move homes. * Wan Ahmad said the use of [[indelible ink]] is "regressive" and only practised in less developed countries. He also raised the possibility of voters not wanting their fingers inked and voters who somehow inked their fingers before voting. Abdul Aziz said the EC was considering a [[biometric]] [[fingerprint]]ing system instead. * Wan Ahmad said a 21-day campaign period is "unnecessary" as Malaysia has a relatively small land area and population. ===Government=== The rally has been roundly criticised by government politicians, who claim that the opposition are using the rally, purportedly a non-partisan protest, to advance its own political agenda.{{cite news |title=Muhyiddin says opposition using Bersih rally to topple BN |url=http://www.themalaysianinsider.com/malaysia/article/muhyiddin-says-opposition-using-bersih-rally-to-topple-bn/ |work=[[The Malaysian Insider]] |date=18 June 2011 |accessdate=21 June 2011}}{{cite news |title=Bersih Assembly Only to Serve the Political Agenda of Opposition Parties |url=http://my.news.yahoo.com/bersih-assembly-only-serve-political-agenda-opposition-parties-063824776.html |work=[[Yahoo! News]] |author=Bernama |authorlink=Bernama |date=17 June 2011 |accessdate=21 June 2011}}{{cite news |title=Bersih being used by the opposition for their agenda, says Chua |url=http://thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=/2011/6/22/nation/8949063&sec=nation |work=[[The Star (Malaysia)|The Star]] |date=22 June 2011 |last=Loh |first=Ivan |accessdate=22 June 2011}}{{cite news |title=Muhyiddin insists Bersih political, threat to security |url=http://www.themalaysianinsider.com/malaysia/article/muhyiddin-insists-bersih-political-threat-to-security/ |work=[[The Malaysian Insider]] |date=25 June 2011 |last=Chi |first=Melissa |accessdate=25 June 2011}} Some ministers also accused the rally organisers of attempting a coup d'état.{{cite news |title=Rais: ‘Bersih in a plot to overthrow govt’ |url=http://www.freemalaysiatoday.com/2011/06/27/rais-bersih-in-a-plot-to-overthrow-govt/ |work=Free Malaysia Today |date=27 June 2011 |last=Lee |first=Patrick |accessdate=27 June 2011}} Prime minister Najib said claims that elections are unfair "did not make sense," adding that the opposition are using instability to their political advantage. He challenged them to take on the government in the polls instead. The Home Minister, Hishamuddin, responding to early reports announcing the rally, criticised public demonstrations in particular. He slammed Bersih for trying to "instill hatred" and "show the world that our country is chaotic." Deputy Prime Minister [[Muhyiddin Yassin]] said the planned rally is "undemocratic" and claimed that it is supported only by a small segment of the population.{{cite news |title=Bersih rally undemocratic, says Muhyiddin |url=http://www.themalaysianinsider.com/malaysia/article/bersih-rally-undemocratic-says-muhyiddin/ |work=[[The Malaysian Insider]] |date=16 June 2011 |author=Asrul Hadi Abdullah Sani |accessdate=16 June 2011}} He also warned of foreign powers taking advantage of instability in Malaysia.{{cite news |title=DPM warns of outside interference |url=http://www.freemalaysiatoday.com/2011/07/02/dpm-warns-of-outside-interference/ |work=Free Malaysia Today |date=2 July 2011 |accessdate=8 July 2011}} ===UMNO=== UMNO's information chief [[Ahmad Maslan]] said that the event might risk damaging the economy and national security.{{cite news |title=Umno against Bersih 2.0, says info chief |url=http://www.themalaysianinsider.com/malaysia/article/umno-against-bersih-2.0-says-info-chief/ |work=[[The Malaysian Insider]] |date=14 June 2011 |accessdate=14 June 2011}} UMNO Youth leader Khairy Jamaluddin said Anwar's attempts to exert influence over the rally on 19 June was proof that Bersih was "compromised" by the opposition. UMNO Youth executive council member Tengku Azman Tengku Zainol Abidin said public rallies should not be held on the streets and that the 2007 Bersih rally "achieved nothing." Anwar's former political secretary [[Dewan Negara|Senator]] Ezam Mohd Noor called Anwar a hypocrite, saying that Anwar's own PKR party election in 2010 was rife with allegations of manipulation.{{cite news |title=Khairy: ‘Stock up’ statement a threat to Chinese community |url=http://thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=/2011/6/21/nation/8941713&sec=nation |work=[[The Star (Malaysia)|The Star]] |date=21 June 2011 |accessdate=21 June 2011}} ===Perkasa=== Perkasa has criticised the rally for threatening to spread chaos, claiming that the opposition will use the rally to trigger an uprising similar to [[2011 Egyptian revolution|Egypt]] and [[2011 Libyan civil war|Libya]]. Perkasa president [[Ibrahim Ali (Malaysia)|Ibrahim Ali]] also threw his support behind the EC, arguing that they had already answered demands for free and fair elections. [[Ibrahim Ali (Malaysia)|Ibrahim Ali]] also warned Chinese community should avoid joining this rally and stay away from it by keeping food at home. ===Independents=== "Independent" Member of Parliament [[Zulkifli Nordin]] questioned the need for the rally, claiming that democracy was already "alive," citing the result of the previous election as an example. Fellow independent MP [[Wee Choo Keong]] hinted that Bersih's cause is "politically motivated," and advised Ambiga to join a political party instead of "hiding behind a non-governmental organisation."{{cite news |title=Go join a political party, Wee tells Ambiga |url=http://thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=/2011/6/15/nation/8901511&sec=nation |work=[[The Star (Malaysia)|The Star]] |date=15 June 2011 |accessdate=15 June 2011}} ===Business=== Sections of the business community initially condemned the proposed street rally, arguing that business operators would have suffered losses on 9 July, a Saturday.{{cite news |title=Group: Bersih demo will be bad for business |url=http://thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=/2011/6/25/nation/8975159&sec=nation |work=[[The Star '''Debiasing''' is the reduction of bias, particularly with respect to [[Heuristics in judgment and decision-making|judgment and decision making]]. [[List of cognitive biases|Biased judgment and decision making]] is that which systematically deviates from the prescriptions of objective standards such as facts, logic, and [[Rational choice theory|rational behavior]] or prescriptive [[Norm (social)|norms]]. Biased judgment and decision making exists in consequential domains such as medicine, law, policy, and business, as well as in everyday life. [[disposition effect|Investors, for example, tend to hold onto falling stocks too long and sell rising stocks too quickly]]. Employers exhibit considerable discrimination in hiring and employment practices,<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/01/04/upshot/the-measuring-sticks-of-racial-bias-.html?_r=0 | title=Racial Bias, Even When We Have Good Intentions | work=The New York Times | date=January 3, 2015 | accessdate=July 25, 2016 | author=Mullainathan, Sendhil}}</ref> and many parents continue to believe that vaccinations cause autism despite knowing that this link is based on falsified evidence.<ref name=":0">{{cite journal|last1 = Morewedge|first1 = C. K.|last2 = Yoon|first2 = H.|last3 = Scopelliti|first3 = I.|last4 = Symborski|first4 = C. W.|last5 = Korris|first5 = J. H.|last6 = Kassam|first6 = K. S.|title = Debiasing Decisions: Improved Decision Making With a Single Training Intervention|journal = Policy Insights from the Behavioral and Brain Sciences|date = 13 August 2015|volume = 2|issue = 1|pages = 129–140|doi = 10.1177/2372732215600886|url = http://bbs.sagepub.com/content/early/2015/08/12/2372732215600886.abstract}}</ref> At an individual level, people who exhibit less decision bias have more intact social environments, reduced risk of alcohol and drug use, lower childhood delinquency rates, and superior planning and problem solving abilities.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Parker|first1=Andrew M.|last2=Fischhoff|first2=Baruch|title=Decision-making competence: External validation through an individual-differences approach|journal=Journal of Behavioral Decision Making|date=January 2005|volume=18|issue=1|pages=1–27|doi=10.1002/bdm.481}}</ref>
Debiasing can occur within the decision maker. For example, a person may learn or adopt better strategies by which to make judgments and decisions.<ref name=":0" /><ref>{{cite book|last1=Larrick|first1=Richard|title=Blackwell handbook of judgment and decision making|date=2004|publisher=Blackwell|location=Malden, Mass. [u.a.]|isbn=978-1-4051-0746-4|pages=316|edition=1st}}</ref> Debiasing can also occur as a result of changes in external factors, such as changing the incentives relevant to a decision or the manner in which the decision is made.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Sunstein|first1=Richard H. Thaler, Cass R.|title=Nudge : improving decisions about health, wealth, and happiness|date=2008|publisher=Yale University Press|location=New Haven, Conn.|isbn=9780300122237|edition=Revised and expanded}}</ref>
There are three general approaches to debiasing judgment and decision making, and the costly errors with which biased judgment and decision making is associated: changing [[incentive]]s, [[Nudge theory|nudging]], and training. Each approach has strengths and weaknesses. For more details, see Morewedge and colleagues (2015).<ref name=":0" />
== General approaches ==
=== Incentives === Changing [[incentive]]s can be an effective means to debias judgment and decision making. This approach is generally derived from [[Rational choice theory|economic theories]] suggesting that people act in their self-interest by seeking to maximize their utility over their lifetime. Many decision making biases may occur simply because they are more costly to eliminate than to ignore.<ref name=":6">{{Cite journal|title = Costs and benefits of judgment errors: Implications for debiasing.|url = http://doi.apa.org/getdoi.cfm?doi=10.1037/0033-2909.110.3.486|journal = Psychological Bulletin|pages = 486–498|volume = 110|issue = 3|doi = 10.1037/0033-2909.110.3.486|first = Hal R.|last = Arkes}}</ref> Making people more accountable for their decisions (increasing incentives), for example, can increase the extent to which they invest cognitive resources in making decisions, leading to less biased decision making when people generally have an idea of how a decision should be made.<ref name=":1">{{cite journal|last1=Lerner|first1=Jennifer S.|last2=Tetlock|first2=Philip E.|title=Accounting for the effects of accountability.|journal=Psychological Bulletin|date=1999|volume=125|issue=2|pages=255–275|doi=10.1037/0033-2909.125.2.255}}</ref> However, "bias" might not be the appropriate term for these types of decision making errors. These "strategy-based" errors occur simply because the necessary effort outweighs the benefit.<ref name=":6" /> If a person makes a suboptimal choice based on an actual bias, then incentives may exacerbate the issue.<ref name=":1" /> An incentive in this case may simply cause the person to perform the suboptimal behavior more enthusiastically.<ref name=":6" />
Incentives can be calibrated to change preferences toward more beneficial behavior. Price cuts on healthy foods increase their consumption in school cafeterias,<ref>{{cite journal|last1=French|first1=SA|title=Pricing effects on food choices.|journal=The Journal of Nutrition|date=2003|volume=133|issue=3|pages=841S-843S|pmid=12612165|url=http://jn.nutrition.org/content/133/3/841S.full}}</ref> and soda taxes appear to reduce soda consumption by the public. People often are willing to use incentives to change their behavior through the means of a commitment device. Shoppers, for example, were willing to forego a cash back rebate on healthy food items if they did not increase the percentage of healthy foods in their shopping baskets.<ref name=":3">{{cite journal|last1=Schwartz|first1=J.|last2=Mochon|first2=D.|last3=Wyper|first3=L.|last4=Maroba|first4=J.|last5=Patel|first5=D.|last6=Ariely|first6=D.|title=Healthier by Precommitment|journal=Psychological Science|date=3 January 2014|volume=25|issue=2|pages=538–546|doi=10.1177/0956797613510950|pmid=24390824}}</ref>
Incentives can backfire when they are miscalibrated or are weaker than social norms that were preventing undesirable behavior. Large incentives can also lead people to choke under pressure.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Ariely|first1=Dan|last2=Gneezy|first2=Uri|last3=Loewenstein|first3=George|last4=Mazar|first4=Nina|title=Large Stakes and Big Mistakes|journal=Review of Economic Studies|date=April 2009|volume=76|issue=2|pages=451–469|doi=10.1111/j.1467-937X.2009.00534.x|url=http://web.stanford.edu/group/SITE/archive/SITE_2006/Web%20Session%207/Ariely_Paper.pdf|deadurl=bot: unknown|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160313202540/http://web.stanford.edu/group/SITE/archive/SITE_2006/Web%20Session%207/Ariely_Paper.pdf|archivedate=2016-03-13|df=}}</ref>
=== Nudges === [[Nudge theory|Nudges]], changes in information presentation or the manner by which judgments and decisions are elicited, is another means to debiasing. People may choose healthier foods if they are better able to understand their nutritional contents,<ref name=":5">{{Cite journal|title = The impact of traffic light color-coding on food health perceptions and choice.|url = http://doi.apa.org/getdoi.cfm?doi=10.1037/xap0000049|journal = Journal of Experimental Psychology: Applied|pages = 255–275|volume = 21|issue = 3|doi = 10.1037/xap0000049|first = Remi|last = Trudel|first2 = Kyle B.|last2 = Murray|first3 = Soyoung|last3 = Kim|first4 = Shuo|last4 = Chen|date= 2015}}</ref> and may choose lower-calorie meals if they are explicitly asked if they would like to downsize their side orders.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Schwartz|first1=J.|last2=Riis|first2=J.|last3=Elbel|first3=B.|last4=Ariely|first4=D.|title=Inviting Consumers To Downsize Fast-Food Portions Significantly Reduces Calorie Consumption|journal=Health Affairs|date=8 February 2012|volume=31|issue=2|pages=399–407|doi=10.1377/hlthaff.2011.0224}}</ref> Other examples of nudges include changing which option is the [[Default effect (psychology)|default]] option to which people will be assigned if they do not choose an alternative option, placing [[Sugary Drinks Portion Cap Rule|a limit on the serving size of soda]], or automatically enrolling employees in a retirement savings program.
=== Training === Training can effectively debias decision makers over the long term.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":2">{{Cite web|title = How a Video Game Helped People Make Better Decisions|url = https://hbr.org/2015/10/how-a-video-game-helped-people-make-better-decisions|website = Harvard Business Review|accessdate = 2015-10-17}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|title = Judgment and Decision Making as a Skill: Learning, Development and Evolution|last = Dhami|first = Mandeep|publisher = Cambridge University Press|year = 2013|isbn = 9781107676527|location = |pages = |url = http://www.cambridge.org/us/academic/subjects/psychology/cognition/judgment-and-decision-making-skill-learning-development-and-evolution}}</ref> Training, to date, has received less attention by academics and policy makers than incentives and nudges because initial debiasing training efforts resulted in mixed success (see Fischhoff, 1982 in Kahneman et al.<ref>{{cite book|chapter=Debiasing|first1=Baruch|last1=Fischhoff|editor-last1=Kahneman|editor-first1=Daniel|editor-last2=Slovic|editor-first2=Paul|editor-last3=Tversky|editor-first3=Amos|title=Judgment Under Uncertainty: Heuristics and Biases|publisher=Cambridge University Press|isbn=9780521284141|chapter-url=https://books.google.com/books/about/Judgment_Under_Uncertainty.html?id=_0H8gwj4a1MC&pg=PA422|language=en}}</ref>). Decision makers could be effectively debiased through training in specific domains. For example, experts can be trained to make very accurate decisions when decision making entails [[Recognition primed decision|recognizing patterns and applying appropriate responses]] in domains such as firefighting, chess, and weather forecasting. Evidence of more general debiasing, across domains and different kinds of problems, however, was not discovered until recently. The reason for the lack of more domain-general debiasing was attributed to experts failing to recognize the underlying "deep structure" of problems in different formats and domains. Weather forecasters are able to predict rain with high accuracy, for example, but show the same overconfidence in their answers to basic trivia questions as other people. An exception was graduate training in scientific fields heavily reliant on statistics such as psychology.<ref name=":4">{{Cite journal|title = Teaching reasoning|url = http://www.sciencemag.org/content/238/4827/625|journal = Science|date = 1987-10-30|issn = 0036-8075|pmid = 3672116|pages = 625–631|volume = 238|issue = 4827|doi = 10.1126/science.3672116|first = R. E.|last = Nisbett|first2 = G. T.|last2 = Fong|first3 = D. R.|last3 = Lehman|first4 = P. W.|last4 = Cheng}}</ref>
Experiments by Morewedge and colleagues (2015) have found interactive computer games and instructional videos can result in long-term debiasing at a general level. In a series of experiments, training with interactive computer games that provided players with personalized feedback, mitigating strategies, and practice, reduced six cognitive biases by more than 30% immediately and by more than 20% as long as three months later. The biased reduced were anchoring, bias blind spot, confirmation bias, fundamental attribution error, projection bias, and representativeness.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":2" />
Training in [[reference class forecasting]] may also improve outcomes. Reference class forecasting is a method for systematically debiasing estimates and decisions, based on what [[Daniel Kahneman]] calls the [[outside view]]. As pointed out by Kahneman in [[Thinking, Fast and Slow]] (p. 252), one of the reasons reference class forecasting is effective for debasing is that, in contrast to conventional forecasting methods, it takes into account the so-called "[[unknown unknowns]]." According to Kahneman, reference class forecasting is effective for debiasing and "has come a long way" in practical implementation since he originally proposed the idea with Amos Tversky (p. 251).
== Sometimes effective strategies ==
=== Incentives === * Paying people for optimal behavior through bonuses or by providing discounts (e.g., to exercise, to take their medication, to trade in fuel inefficient vehicles such as the "[[Car Allowance Rebate System|cash for clunkers]]" program).<ref>{{Cite journal|title = The effect of accuracy motivation on anchoring and adjustment: Do people adjust from provided anchors?|url = http://doi.apa.org/getdoi.cfm?doi=10.1037/a0021540|journal = Journal of Personality and Social Psychology|pages = 917–932|volume = 99|issue = 6|doi = 10.1037/a0021540|first = Joseph P.|last = Simmons|first2 = Robyn A.|last2 = LeBoeuf|first3 = Leif D.|last3 = Nelson|pmid=21114351}}</ref> * Taxing people for suboptimal behavior (e.g., drinking soda, smoking tobacco, and weed).
=== Nudges === * Using [[default effect]] to [[nudge theory|nudge people]] towards decisions optimal for the decision maker or society. * [[Commitment device]]s that makes it more costly to make suboptimal decisions (e.g., Schwartz et al., 2014<ref name=":3" />). * [[Framing (social sciences)|Reframing]] choice options in ways that make important attributes salient. Labeling hamburger meat 25% fat, for example, makes people more sensitive to fat content than labeling it 75% lean. * Presenting information in formats that make critical information easier to evaluate, such as displaying nutritional value using a "traffic light" system.<ref name=":5" />
=== Training === * Providing people with personalized feedback regarding the direction and degree to which they exhibit bias.<ref name=":0" /> * Teaching a "consider-the-alternative" strategy, such as considering a plausible alternative reason for an event than cause one suspects.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Hirt|first1=Edward R.|last2=Markman|first2=Keith D.|title=Multiple explanation: A consider-an-alternative strategy for debiasing judgments.|journal=Journal of Personality and Social Psychology|date=1995|volume=69|issue=6|pages=1069–1086|doi=10.1037/0022-3514.69.6.1069}}</ref> * Teaching people statistical reasoning and normative rules of which they are unaware.<ref name=":4" /> * Encouraging people to take the perspective of a person who will experience the consequences of their decision can reduce bias. Participants who were shown a "morphed" image of their face to resemble themselves upon retirement were more likely to save money for the future rather than elect to receive it in the present.<ref>{{Cite journal|title = Increasing Saving Behavior Through Age-Progressed Renderings of the Future Self|url = http://journals.ama.org/doi/abs/10.1509/jmkr.48.SPL.S23|journal = Journal of Marketing Research|date = 2011-11-01|issn = 0022-2437|pmc = 3949005|pmid = 24634544|pages = S23-S37|volume = 48|issue = SPL|doi = 10.1509/jmkr.48.SPL.S23|first = Hal E|last = Hershfield|first2 = Daniel G|last2 = Goldstein|first3 = William F|last3 = Sharpe|first4 = Jesse|last4 = Fox|first5 = Leo|last5 = Yeykelis|first6 = Laura L|last6 = Carstensen|first7 = Jeremy N|last7 = Bailenson}}</ref> * Encourage, incentivize, or make mandatory the use of [[reference class forecasting]]. [[Reference class forecasting]] was made mandatory in Great Britain and Denmark for large government infrastructure projects with the explicit purpose of eliminating [[optimism bias]].
== See also == * [[Cognitive bias mitigation]] * [[Cognitive bias modification]] * [[Cognitive vulnerability]] * [[Reference class forecasting]]
